(TB3) +1 point for any plausible/reasonable example Examples include: - Unintended consequences, such as unintentionally altering other genes - leading to harmful effects - Off-target effects such as future generations - Consent (future individuals of that same bloodline never directly gave consent and wouldn’t be able to ever/in the first place) - Equity and access is also another ethical issue because this could widen the gap between the upper/lower class because of inaccessible technology to many - “Selective Breeding” in humans, which is basically designer babies - where enhancements aren’t made for the sake of disease/disorder but for traits like height and appearance For the graders: It should probably be pretty easy to understand the question and the explanation, so if it seems completely off don’t give points!

answer: The molecular clock hypothesis, proposed by Zuckerkandl and Pauling, suggests that amino acid substitutions in proteins accumulate at a relatively constant rate over evolutionary time. However, substitution rates may vary depending on the protein’s functional importance. (10) Info: Proteins X and Y differ in both length and substitution rate. Protein X is 400 amino acids in length with a substitution rate of 0.625 x 10^-9 substitutions per site/year. Protein Y on the other hand is 600 amino acids long with a substitution rate of 1.25 x 10^-9 substitutions per site/year a. How many substitutions were expected to be accumulated at a maximum between human and mouse, which diverged 80 million years ago (MYA)? (4) Answer: X: 40 substitutions ; Y: 120 subsitutions +1 point for correct number of protein X substitutions +1 point for correct number of protein Y substitutions +2 points for proper work shown/any work shown with the info given is +1 Explanation of the work from writer: Protein X: Given: 400 amino acids, rate of 0.625 x 10^-9 subsitutions/site/year, and a divergence time of 80 million years (80 mil to sci notation would be 8.0 x 10^7, in the work shown below) X substitutions = 400 x 0.625 x 10^-19 x 2 x 8.0 x 10^7 = 40 Protein Y: Given the same info, except that the rate is 1.25 x 10^-19 Y substitutions = 600 x 1.25 x 10^-9 x 2 x 8.0 x 10^7 = 120 b. In Protein X, 6 amino acid substitutions were observed between human and a mammal species. What would be the divergence time between them? (2) This is exactly like how the work was shown for 41a, except THIS time you are given observed substitutions and are to solve for divergence time. 6 = 400 x 0.625 x 10^-9 x 2 x t (where t is just the divergence time) Answer: 12 MYA +1 point for correct answer +1 point for proper work shown with info given/any work is okay c. Insulin is first made as one long protein chain consisting of 110 amino acids. During processing, two parts are removed: a signal segment of 24 amino acids at the start and a middle segment of 31 amino acids. This leaves the primary active region of 55 amino acids, which functions as the mature insulin hormone. Rank the subsitution rates of each domain from highest to lowest. Justify your reasoning (4) (TB2) +1 point for correct ranking, must be ALL correct (signal domain > middle segment > primary active region) +1 point x3 for each of the explanations (justifications) - The signal segment is removed early during maturation and is less important for the final function, so it can tolerate more changes = highest substitution - The middle segment is also removed before insulin becomes active, but has a role during processing so its substitution rate is in the middle - The primary active region is the active part of insulin responsible for hormone function. Because it is so important it is heavily conserved and changes very slowly = lowest substitution rate

question: While analyzing a DNA microarray, Heather notices that some genes appear brighter than others. They also appear red on the tray. What does this mean, and what could have caused it? Why are these experiments important? (6)
source: 2026 Captain Summer Exchange C_TEST_Designer Genes_Arcadia High School_CSE2025.pdf
answer: While analyzing a DNA microarray, Heather notices that some genes appear brighter than others. They also appear red on the tray. What does this mean, and what could have caused it? Why are these experiments important? (6) The bright red spot signals increased transcription and protein production for a mutant variation of the gene being studied. This could have caused by a cancerous mutation. These experiments allow scientists to understand DNA-protein relationships and determine mutations that cause cancer and genes that are cancer-prone.

question: List four steps of Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism. Make sure that you are detailed in your description. (4)
source: 2026 Captain Summer Exchange C_TEST_Designer Genes_Arcadia High School_CSE2025.pdf
answer: List four steps of Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism. Make sure that you are detailed in your description. (4) The DNA is taken from cells using chemicals that break apart the membrane. Then, DNA is treated with restriction enzymes to cut the DNA at recognition sequences. DNA is then electrophoresed so that the fragments are sorted by length. The fragments are southern blotted to a membrane and hybridized to a probe.

Which of the following correctly describes the mutation to the NF1 gene?

options.label: a
options.text: Mutations can cause the gradual collapse of a species due to inactivation of important genes.

options.label: b
options.text: Unedited mRNA can cause proteins to misfold due to additional amino acids.

options.label: c
options.text: Cellular conditions allow for the same codon to code for more than one amino acid.

options.label: d

options.label: e
options.text: Multiple codons can specify a specific amino acid through wobble base pairing.

question: Why is rRNA used for phylogenetic analysis compared to other RNA molecules?

options.label: a
options.text: Because of its conserved stem-loop structures and sequence variability, rRNA can be used to achieve higher resolution in phylogenetic trees.

options.label: b
options.text: rRNA in species evolve under relaxed constraint, and an organism’s molecular clock can be used to track evolutionary history.

options.label: c
options.text: rRNA is scarce in prokaryotic cells, allowing for scientists to ignore the Bacteria and Archaea domains.

options.label: d
options.text: Translational selection does not affect rRNA transcripts because it is a non-coding region, creating a conserved region for comparison.

options.label: e
options.text: rRNA genes are located in chromosomes whose synteny (localization in the chromosome) is conserved across species.

question: What correctly explains the difference between cis- and trans-acting factors in gene expression?

options.label: a
options.text: Cis-acting factors can only affect a single allele. Trans-acting factors are able to affect both alleles.

options.label: b
options.text: Cis-acting factors are typically proteins which affect gene expression. Trans-acting factors are typically RNA molecules that bind to DNA.

options.label: c
options.text: Cis-acting factors bind to and modify ribosomes. Trans-acting factors bind to and modify histone tails.

options.label: d
options.text: Cis-acting factors are defined by their mobility. Trans-acting factors are defined by their fixed position.

options.label: e
options.text: Cis-acting factors are the translated parts of mRNA. Trans-acting factors are the untranslated parts of mRNA.

options.label: e
options.text: It is involved in initiating the development of testis by creating a certain transcription factor.

question: You’re researching mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) and are comparing it to nuclear DNA. After running gel electrophoresis, you notice that the mtDNA genome is smaller than the nuclear genome. You decide to examine the mtDNA and uncover that the mitochondrial genome contains genes coding for the production of rRNAs, ATP synthase, and citrate synthase. You identified a protein called TFAM (protein involved in mitochondrial genome replication) present in cells before running the gel, but you cannot seem to find the appropriate sequence in the mtDNA. What is the most likely reason you cannot find the TFAM gene?

options.label: a
options.text: Mitochondrial proteins need to constantly be phosphorylated in order to maintain their proper structure.

options.label: b
options.text: The TFAM gene from the mtDNA was translocated into the nuclear DNA of the cell.

options.label: c
options.text: The mitochondrial genome is redundant with the nuclear genome and lost the TFAM gene as a result.

options.label: d
options.text: The TFAM gene is located in the nuclear genome, and the proteins are transported to the mitochondria.

options.label: e
options.text: TFAM is synthesized in the cytosol after the mitochondrial mRNA transcript leaves the organelle and then is returned back to the mitochondria once completed.

question: Geraniums are a unique plant species which follow a biparental mode of inheritance for chloroplasts. Your local botanist has decided to cross wild type green-leafed geraniums with mutant white-leafed geraniums. The resulting offspring include phenotypes of green-leafed plants, white-leafed plants, and variegated plants. What is the most likely explanation for the variegated geraniums?

options.label: a
options.text: The geranium gametes mutated to produce the variegated offspring.

options.label: b
options.text: The cpDNA recombined with the nuclear DNA of the plant cells.

options.label: c
options.text: The parent generation were infected by a virus that contaminated the offspring.

options.label: d
options.text: The variegated geraniums are a result of heteroplasmy due to the mode of inheritance.

options.label: e
options.text: The chloroplast alleles from each parent are codominant with one another.

question: Your partner has decided to use a 2 color DNA microarray to test the water retention of a plant. A red fluorescence indicates a drought-stressed plant, and a green fluorescence indicates a well-watered plant. When they go to examine the slide, they notice yellow fluorescence from some of the spots on the slide. What is the reason for the yellow spots?

options.label: a
options.text: RNA has degraded in the sample due to an error in preparation.

options.label: b
options.text: The microarrays were not properly labeled with the fluorescent markers.

options.label: c
options.text: Residual genomic DNA bound to the microarrays and are synthesizing an unintended marker.

options.label: d
options.text: There is an equal expression of well-watered and drought-stressed proteins.

options.label: e
options.text: Nonspecific hybridization occurred with the RNA.

question: Use the image for reference to the following scenario. A classroom is doing a lab experiment where they are doing RFPL analysis of a tomato. options.text: The DNA sample had too many restriction enzymes added, fragmenting the DNA into undetectable pieces.

question: A gene duplication event creates two paralogs. Over evolutionary time, one copy acquires a new function. This is:

options.label: e
options.text: Epistasis 15 Free Response I: The Hox Paradox of Ultrabithorax The fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster is a commonly used model organism because of the plethora of genetic tools available. They are also notable for their role in the discovery of Hox genes, which encode transcription factors that control gene regulatory networks that determine body plan development. In this problem, we will investigate the use of balancer chromosomes, some genetic tools for investigating cell-type specific effects, and the role of the Hox transcription factor Ultrabithorax. One of the most critical parts of Drosophila is the maintenance of stable stocks that preserve the same genetics over many generations. For example, incorporating a transgene into a chromosome that can then recombine could lead to researchers losing track of what flies have the transgene and on which chromosome, which would not be ideal. Drosophila flies are diploid and have four chromosomes (3 autosomes and 1 sex chromosome). Typically only the 3 autosomes are used for genetic experiments and are denoted as follows: Chr1:allele 1 / Chr1: allele 2 ; Chr2: allele 1 / Chr2: allele 2 ; Chr3: allele 1 / Chr3: allele 2 In order to make sure the alleles are trackable, researchers use balancer chromosomes, which contain large inversions and also have phenotypic markers that allow them to be tracked visually both in the adult stage and in the larval stage. One common balancer fly is the following with the physical markers listed below: yw; Pin / CyO-GFP ; MKRS / TM6B, tb ; +/+ yw: red eyes Pin: thinner and slightly shorter hairs on the back of the adult thorax, no larval marker CyO-GFP: curly wings in the adult, expresses GFP during larval and adult stages MKRS: extremely short hairs on the back of the adult thorax, no larval marker TM6B: additional hairs on the humerus (shoulder) of the adult fly tb (tubby): a larval marker that causes pupa to become shorter

source: 2026 Columbia C_CU Science Olympiad 2026 - Designer Genes - Exam - 20251218.pdf

question: Explain what an inversion is and list four other types of chromosomal abnormalities (5 pts). These balancer chromosomes are useful because they maintain heterozygosity, which is especially critical if the homozygous allele is embryonically lethal. While these balancer chromosomes still contain the proper machinery to undergo recombination, no recombinant offspring are observed from flies with balancer chromosomes. 16
source: 2026 Columbia C_CU Science Olympiad 2026 - Designer Genes - Exam - 20251218.pdf

question: Why does the large inversion on balancer chromosomes prevent offspring from being homozygous for the balancer? Explain why no recombinant offspring are observed. (5 pts). One common genetic system in Drosophila is known as the UAS-Gal4 system to achieve cell-type specific control. In this system, the expression of a transcription factor derived from yeast, Gal4, is placed under the control of a cell-type specific enhancer. Gal4 can then bind to an upstream activating sequence (UAS) enhancer, which in turn drives the expression of another gene of interest, such as protein tagged with GFP. Commonly, fly lines containing the Gal4 only are crossed to lines containing the UAS-gene only. Individually, these fly lines behave normally since the Gal4 and UAS components are separated. Their progeny are then screened for those containing both Gal4 and UAS components, meaning that the system is properly combined and the gene of interest is being expressed.

Describe what events must occur between Gal4 binding to the UAS enhancer and transcription of the gene of interest? (5 pts) Our protein of interest is the Hox gene Ultrabithorax, abbreviated Ubx. The wing and haltere of the fly are serially homologous structures and are uniquely specified by the absence or presence of Ubx, respectively. That is, loss of Ubx expression in the haltere leads to the development of an extra pair of wings, known as the “bithorax” phenotype where the fly has four wings. Consider the four genetic constructs Actin-Gal4, Ubx-Gal4, UAS-Ubx-RNAi, and UAS-Ubx-GFP. 17

(6 pts) Cancer is a group of diseases that all share a common theme: a loss of control over the cell cycle. The cell cycle is highly regulated by a variety of classes of proteins, including oncogenes (called proto-oncogenes in a pre-cancerous context) and tumor suppressors. These genes promote and suppress progression of the cell cycle, respectively.

question: What specific type of mutation in proto-oncogenes will cause tumor formation? What about tumor suppressors? (2 pts) TP53 is one of the most frequently mutated genes across all cancers. It’s a tumor suppressor and is commonly known as the “guardian of the genome,” producing the transcription factor p53. It’s activated by many cellular stressors, including DNA damage, in which case it decides whether to repair the damage or undergo apoptosis. TP53 is commonly mutated in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), so called because it lacks receptors for estrogen (ER), progesterone (PR), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2).

answer: Sanger sequencing uses the same basic principles as PCR, but there is one major addition to a Sanger sequencing reaction. What reagent is added for Sanger sequencing that is not present in PCR, and how does this change the process? How do they function to sequence a piece of DNA? (4 points) Solution: Sanger sequencing adds ddNTPs with fluorochromes (fluorescent dideoxynucleotides) [+1] which can still be added to newly synthesized strands but interrupt DNA synthesis [+1]. When they are added, they stop replication, fixing the strand at its current length [+1]. Then, when run on a gel to separate the various strands by length, they can be read with fluorescent imaging to see which nucleotides are in each position [+1]. For questions 44 and 45, consider the following situation: two pea plants with the following genotypes are crossed: GG HH x gg hh. The resulting F1 generation, having the genotype Gg Hh, is backcrossed to the recessive parent.

answer: When making a plasmid for blue-white screening, where should the gene of interest be inserted? What effect does this have on the mutated protein? (3 points) Solution: The gene should be inserted in the middle of the lacZa sequence of the plasmid [+1]. Normally, the lacZa fragment combines with the mutated lacZ to create functional β-galactosidase, which turns the cells blue when exposed to X-gal [+1]. However, if the fragment is properly interrupted by the gene, β-galactosidase is not functional, so the cell stays white [+1].

answer: They estimate that C. ezrii has a genome around 3.5 million base pairs long. Also, because they are very excited to share their findings, they want to sequence the whole genome as quickly as possible. Which sequencing technique should they use: Sanger, Illumina, Nanopore, or a combination of these? Explain your answer, including why the other option(s) are not good choices. (4 points) Solution: They should use a combination of Nanopore and Illumina sequencing [+1]. Nanopore sequencing has a very high throughput, able to sequence millions of base pairs at once, which is great for speed [+1]. However, it is less accurate than the other methods, so Illumina sequencing can be used to fix errors and clear up unresolved sections [+1]. Sanger sequencing could also be used in place of Illumina sequencing, but even though it has a higher accuracy, it is much slower, and thus would not suit the needs of the team [+1]. Max 2/4 if they missed the first point but still gave justification Upon analysis, C. ezrii was found to have a unique gene regulation system for the protein cayugin. In the presence of the transcription factor CgI, cayugin expression is significantly reduced.

answer: Why are antibiotic resistance genes usually included in the inserted plasmid? (2 points) Solution: It allows the researchers to select for bacteria that took up the plasmid [+1]. When exposed to the antibiotic, the non-transformed bacteria will die, leaving only the transformed bacteria to study [+1].

question: [4 pts] Ten wild-type female zebrafish are crossed to ten male zebrafish which lack tails. This tailless phenotype is caused by a recessive mutation in the no tail (ntl) gene. Each female zebrafish only mates once and gives birth to 100 baby fish. Of the 1,000 total offspring, 200 lacked tails and 800 had tails. Given this, how many of the original female zebrafish were heterozygous? Blue-white screening is a molecular biology technique used to identify recombinant bacterial colonies. In E. coli, the lac operon plays a central role in this process. When a gene of interest is inserted into the lacZ gene of a plasmid, it disrupts the production of β-galactosidase, an enzyme that normally cleaves X-gal, a substrate. E. coli cells are plated on agar containing X-gal and IPTG (an inducer of the lac operon). ● Blue colonies: These arise from bacteria where the lacZ gene is intact. The β-galactosidase enzyme is functional, cleaving X-gal and producing a blue color. ● White colonies: These result from bacteria where the lacZ gene is disrupted due to the insertion of the foreign gene. Without functional β-galactosidase, no blue color is produced. Thus, white colonies indicate successful cloning (gene insertion), while blue colonies suggest unsuccessful cloning. This makes blue-white screening a simple and effective method to identify recombinant E. coli strains.
answer: [4 pts] Ten wild-type female zebrafish are crossed to ten male zebrafish which lack tails. This tailless phenotype is caused by a recessive mutation in the no tail (ntl) gene. Each female zebrafish only mates once and gives birth to 100 baby fish. Of the 1,000 total offspring, 200 lacked tails and 800 had tails. Given this, how many of the original female zebrafish were heterozygous? 4 females Only a Nn x nn cross has a chance (50%) to result in tailless offspring. If each cross generates 100 offspring, then you would need 4 crosses (100 * 0.5 * 4) to generate 200 tailless fish. Blue-white screening is a molecular biology technique used to identify recombinant bacterial colonies. In E. coli, the lac operon plays a central role in this process. When a gene of interest is inserted into the lacZ gene of a plasmid, it disrupts the production of β-galactosidase, an enzyme that normally cleaves X-gal, a substrate. E. coli cells are plated on agar containing X-gal and IPTG (an inducer of the lac operon). ● Blue colonies: These arise from bacteria where the lacZ gene is intact. The β-galactosidase enzyme is functional, cleaving X-gal and producing a blue color. ● White colonies: These result from bacteria where the lacZ gene is disrupted due to the insertion of the foreign gene. Without functional β-galactosidase, no blue color is produced. Thus, white colonies indicate successful cloning (gene insertion), while blue colonies suggest unsuccessful cloning. This makes blue-white screening a simple and effective method to identify recombinant E. coli strains. ---------------------------------------------------

Blue-white screening is a molecular biology technique used to identify recombinant bacterial colonies. In E. coli, the lac operon plays a central role in this process. When a gene of interest is inserted into the lacZ gene of a plasmid, it disrupts the production of β-galactosidase, an enzyme that normally cleaves X-gal, a substrate. E. coli cells are plated on agar containing X-gal and IPTG (an inducer of the lac operon). ● Blue colonies: These arise from bacteria where the lacZ gene is intact. The β-galactosidase enzyme is functional, cleaving X-gal and producing a blue color. ● White colonies: These result from bacteria where the lacZ gene is disrupted due to the insertion of the foreign gene. Without functional β-galactosidase, no blue color is produced. Thus, white colonies indicate successful cloning (gene insertion), while blue colonies suggest unsuccessful cloning. This makes blue-white screening a simple and effective method to identify recombinant E. coli strains. ---------------------------------------------------

question: (2.00 pts) Describe how diﬀerential gene expression between two conditions (e.g. treated vs control cells) could be assayed using RNA-Seq. Outline the main steps from sample collection to data analysis, and discuss how you would account for technical and biological variation.
answer: (2.00 pts) Expected Answer: Design a guide RNA (gRNA) that specifically targets an early exon of gene X, selecting a unique 20-nt sequence plus PAM. Transfect cells with Cas9 + gRNA, along with (optionally) a repair template if you want to insert a marker or induce a defined mutation via homology-directed repair (HDR). Controls: non-targeting gRNA control (to tes for off-target/exp editing effects), “mock-transfection” control, and (if using HDR) a template-only control. To verify knockout: PCR amplify and sequence the target locus to confirm indels; qPCR / Western blot to check for loss of mRNA / protein; functional assay if appropriate. For off-target assessment: use whole-genome sequencing (or targeted off-target site sequencing predicted by bioinformatics) in clones; perform phenotypic comparison with control clones; optionally use a Cas9 variant with higher specificity. Expected Answer: Sample A shows two bands (500 bp & 520 bp): likely heterozygous for an indel (one allele with insertion/deletion, one allele wild-type). Sample B with single 520 bp band likely homozygous for the larger (wild-type or insertion) allele. Genotype: A = heterozygote (indel/normal), B = homozygote (no indel or insertion). Complications: PCR bias — sometimes shorter fragments amplify preferentially, leading to over-representation. Also, if the indel is large, secondary structure or GC-rich region may affect amplification. Finally, somatic mosaicism (if cells are not clonal) can complicate interpretation. 12/22/25, 3:14 PM scilympiad.com/hylas/Es/PrevTestAns?tid=000GX7 https://scilympiad.com/hylas/Es/PrevTestAns?tid=000GX7 4/7 Describe how differential gene expression between two conditions (e.g. treated vs control cells) could be assayed using RNA-Seq. Outline the main steps from sample collection to data analysis, and discuss how you would account for technical and biological variation.

question: (2.00 pts) Given a plasmid cloning experiment: you digest both plasmid vector and insert with the same restriction enzyme (producing compatible overhangs), ligate, then transform into bacteria. Only a small fraction (<1%) of colonies have the correct insert orientation. Propose at least three reasons for this low eﬃciency and how you might improve yield of correct clones.
answer: (2.00 pts) Given a plasmid cloning experiment: you digest both plasmid vector and insert with the same restriction enzyme (producing compatible overhangs), ligate, then transform into bacteria. Only a small fraction (<1%) of colonies have the correct insert orientation. Propose at least three reasons for this low efficiency and how you might improve yield of correc clones. Expected Answer: Steps: isolate total RNA from treated and control cells → quality control (e.g. Bioanalyzer) → prepare RNA-Seq libraries (e.g. poly-A selection or ribosomal RNA depletion) → sequence on NGS platform → obtain raw reads → map reads to reference genome → count reads per gene/transcript → normalize counts (e.g. TPM, RPKM, or using methods for count data) → statistical differential expression analysis (e.g. DESeq2, edgeR). To account for variation: include biological replicates (multiple independent samples per condition), include technical replicates if possible, randomize processing order, include spike-in controls or internal standards, perform batch effect correction if needed (e.g. using PCA / batch covariates), and apply multiple-testing correction (e.g. Benjamini–Hochberg) when calling differential expression. Expected Answer: Under Hardy–Weinberg: p² = 0.49, 2pq = 2 × 0.7 × 0.3 = 0.42, q² = 0.09. So expected frequencies: AA = 0.49, Aa = 0.42, aa = 0.09. Observing deviations could be due to non-random mating (inbreeding or assortative mating), selection (one genotype has higher fitness), genetic drift (especially if population small), gene flow (migration), mutation, or sampling error. To test: assess mating patterns; measure fitness of genotypes; track allele frequencies over generations; use large sample size; test for population structure; estimate effective population size; test for recent migration; directly genotype large number of individuals. Expected Answer: A frameshift mutation alters the reading frame for all downstream codons, often producing a completely different (garbage) amino acid sequence and likely encountering a premature stop codon. This typically abolishes proper folding, disrupts functional domains, and often leads to truncated nonfunctional protein or nonsense-mediate mRNA decay. In contrast, a missense mutation near the C-terminus changes only one amino acid; if that region is outside critical functional domains, the protein may retain substantial function, making the phenotypic effect milder. Expected Answer: Possible reasons for low correct-insert yield: Vector recircularization without insert (ligase seals vector alone) → background. Insert ligated in wrong orientation (because overhangs are symmetric or compatible in both orientations). Inefficient ligation or transformation (low DNA purity, suboptimal ratio of vector:insert, low competent cell efficiency). To improve: dephosphorylate vector ends to reduce recircularization; use directional cloning (two different restriction enzymes to force orientation specificity); gel-purify insert and vector; optimize vector-to-insert molar ratio; use high-efficiency competent cells; screen larger number of colonies; use antibiotic and blue/white or negative selection to enrich correct clones; include negative control (vector only) to estimate background. 12/22/25, 3:14 PM scilympiad.com/hylas/Es/PrevTestAns?tid=000GX7 https://scilympiad.com/hylas/Es/PrevTestAns?tid=000GX7 5/7

question: (2.00 pts) In a eukaryotic cell, you observe that a particular gene’s pre-mRNA is alternatively spliced, giving rise to two isoforms: one including exon 3, and one skipping it. How might such alternative splicing evolve, and what evolutionary advantages might alternative splicing confer at the population or species level?
answer: (2.00 pts) In a eukaryotic cell, you observe that a particular gene’s pre-mRNA is alternatively spliced, giving rise to two isoforms: one including exon 3, and one skipping it. How might such alternative splicing evolve, and what evolutionary advantages might alternative splicing confer at the population or species level? Expected Answer: Epigenetics: heritable changes in gene expression that do not involve changes in the DNA sequence. Mechanisms include: DNA methylation (e.g. CpG methylation), histone modification (acetylation, methylation, etc.), chromatin remodeling, non-coding RNAs (e.g. miRNAs, lncRNAs), and chromatin structure / 3D genome architecture. Experimental strategy: isolate genomic DNA and chromatin from diseased vs healthy tissue; perform bisulfite sequencing (or methylation array) for DNA methylation; perform ChIP-Seq for key histone marks (e.g. H3K27ac, H3K9me3); RNA-Seq to measure expression; perhaps ATAC-Seq / DNase-seq for chromatin accessibility. Correlate epigenetic modifications with gene Y expression differences. Use demethylating agents or histone-deacetylase inhibitors in cell-based models to test whether changes in epigeneti marks cause expression changes. Expected Answer: Data: collect nucleotide or protein sequences of the two genes and related homologs from several species; align sequences; build phylogenetic tree (e.g. maximum likelihood, Bayesian). Interpretation: if the two genes from different species group with orthologous genes (each clusters with its species’ orthologs across species), that suggests speciation events — orthologs. If the two genes from the same species cluster together (forming a species-specific clade), that suggests a gene duplication within that lineage — paralogs. Additional support: synteny (conserved gene order), chromosome location, intron-exon structure, and similarity of non-coding regulatory regions. Expected Answer: Process: preload and normalize raw intensity data (background correction, log-transform, quantile normalization, etc.). Filter out low-quality/low-signal probes. Perform statistical tests (e.g. t-test or linear model for each gene) comparing conditions. Adjust for multiple comparisons (e.g. apply False Discovery Rate correction like Benjamini– Hochberg). Optionally, use more sophisticated modelling (limma package) to include batch effects or other covariates. Then set significance thresholds (e.g. adjusted p-value < 0.05 fold-change cut-off) to define differentially expressed genes. Validate key hits (e.g. by qPCR). Expected Answer: Evolution: alternative splicing may evolve via mutations in splice sites, regulatory sequences (enhancers/silencers), exon duplication/deletion, or changes in splicing factor expression/regulation. Isoforms may be preserved if they confer selective advantage. Advantages: increases proteomic diversity without increasing genome size; 12/22/25, 3:14 PM scilympiad.com/hylas/Es/PrevTestAns?tid=000GX7 https://scilympiad.com/hylas/Es/PrevTestAns?tid=000GX7 6/7

question: (2.00 pts) Explain how random mutagenesis and targeted mutagenesis diﬀer. Give an example of when each would be used. What are the advantages and disadvantages of each? Designer Genes C - Designer Genes - Hylas SO - 12-07-2025 Instructions Now is a good time to put your cellular device(s) away. Please get out all the materials you will need for this event (Note sheets/binders/calculators/ﬁeld guides/or anything else allowed in the oﬃcial rule book of your event). Best of luck!
answer: (2.00 pts) Explain how random mutagenesis and targeted mutagenesis differ. Give an example of when each would be used. What are the advantages and disadvantages of each? allows tissue-specific or developmental-stage–specific isoforms; enables fine regulation of gene function; may facilitate adaptation by allowing organisms to respond flexibly to environmental changes; can mask deleterious mutations by modulating which isoform is expressed. Expected Answer: Mitochondrial inheritance: mitochondria (and their mtDNA) are inherited maternally because during fertilization the sperm’s mitochondria are typically degraded or excluded; thus all mtDNA comes from the egg. Differences in evolutionary dynamics: mtDNA is haploid and doesn’t recombine (or recombines very little), so its effective population size is smaller, making genetic drift stronger. Mutations can accumulate quickly, and deleterious mutations may be less efficiently purged. Also, heteroplasmy (mixture of mutant and wild-type mtDNA in a cell) adds complexity; selection may act at the organelle or cellular level. Expected Answer: Random mutagenesis: introducing mutations across the genome (or gene) without specific target (e.g. via chemical mutagens, UV, transposon insertions, error- prone PCR). Used to generate diversity, discover gene function, perform forward genetic screens. Advantages: unbiased, can reveal unexpected gene functions; high diversity. Disadvantages: many mutations are deleterious or irrelevant, mapping causative mutation is laborious, off-target effects, background noise. Targeted mutagenesis: precise modification at a chosen locus (e.g. via CRISPR-Cas9, homologous recombination, site-directed mutagenesis). Used to test specific hypotheses (e.g. change a residue, knock out gene, insert tag). Advantages: clean, precise, hypothesis-driven, minimal off-target changes. Disadvantages: may miss unanticipated effects elsewhere; needs knowledge of sequence and function; sometimes technical difficulty (efficiency, delivery, repair). © 2025 - powered by Scilympiad (https://scilympiad.com) | Tournaments (/hylas/Home/Subscribers?sort=t) | Support Us (/hylas/Give) Terms of Use (/ToS.html) | Privacy (/Privacy.html) | Cookie Policy (/CookiePolicy.html) | Support (/hylas/Support) | Contact (/hylas/Home/Contact) 12/22/25, 3:14 PM scilympiad.com/hylas/Es/PrevTestAns?tid=000GX7 https://scilympiad.com/hylas/Es/PrevTestAns?tid=000GX7 7/7

answer: (5 points) Suppose there is a mutation in the chiasmata during meiosis in a female mouse. If the resulting cell is fertilized, what effects, if any, might this mutation have on the resulting offspring? For full points, you must explain each of the following: (a) (2 points) What is the normal function of chiasmata, and what effects does their disruption lead to? Solution: Chiasmata are points where homologous chromosomes remain connected during meiosis I after crossing over (+1). Their disruption leads to nondisjunction mutations and reduced amounts of crossing over (+1). (b) (1 point) How would this mutation affect genetic diversity? Why? Solution: Decrease (+0.5), as there may be fewer crossing over events, leading to reduced genetic diversity in offspring (+0.5) (c) (2 points) Express the changes in allele frequencies through Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium (in terms of p and q). What does this mean for the relative abundance of each possible phenotype? Solution: p would decrease (+0.5), q would increase (+0.5). There’d be increased abundance of the recessive phenotype (+1).

question: (5 points) Consider the following statements about heritability. State whether each is true or false (you must give the full word!). Additionally, if and only if the statement is false, write the single word that makes it incorrect, and write the single word that would make the statement true. (a) Realized heritability is sometimes greater than the true narrow-sense heritability of a trait. (b) Quantitative trait locus (QTL) studies can capture the broad-sense heritability of traits. (c) Suppose trait A has a correlation coefficient of 0.6, calculated from comparing parents and their offspring. Trait B has the same correlation coefficient of 0.6, calculated from comparing cousins. Trait B has the higher heritability.
answer: (5 points) Consider the following statements about heritability. State whether each is true or false (you must give the full word!). Additionally, if and only if the statement is false, write the single word that makes it incorrect, and write the single word that would make the statement true. (a) Realized heritability is sometimes greater than the true narrow-sense heritability of a trait. Solution: True (+1) Explanation: Experimental noise alone can lead to an estimate of realized heritability greater than the true narrow-sense heritability (among other factors). (b) Quantitative trait locus (QTL) studies can capture the broad-sense heritability of traits. Solution: False (+1). Incorrect part: broad (+1). Correct replacement: narrow (+1). Explanation: QTL studies associate variation in single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) to levels of a quantitative phenotype. Since dominance/epistatic effects can only be observed from whole genes and not individual SNPs, QTL studies effectively seek to uncover additive genetic effects on a trait. (c) Suppose trait A has a correlation coefficient of 0.6, calculated from comparing parents and their offspring. Trait B has the same correlation coefficient of 0.6, calculated from comparing cousins. Trait B has the higher heritability. Solution: True (+1) Explanation: Since cousins are more distantly related than parents/offspring, if we observe the same degree of correlation in traits A and B, variance in B should be more strongly governed by genetic factors (i.e., be more heritable) than variance in A. In this scenario, prokaryotes use transfer-messenger RNA (tmRNA) to remedy this. Refer to Image 8 for the structure of tmRNA. Using it, answer the following questions. (a) (2 points) Looking at the structure of the tmRNA, what qualities make it similar to tRNA? What qualities make it similar to mRNA? (b) (2 points) It has also been found that, after tmRNA functions, the misread proteins are quickly proteolyzed by the prokaryotic cell. Given its similarities in structure to both tRNA and mRNA, propose a mechanism for tmRNA in resolving stalled ribosomes. (c) (2 points) Aminoglycosides such as streptomycin function by binding to ribosomal subunits, causing the ribosome to “misread” certain codons and incorrect translation to take place. In bacterial species that have upregulated tmRNA production, how do you expect them to respond to treatment with streptomycin? Why?
answer: (6 points) Occasionally, there are times when prokaryotes may become “stuck” during translation - for example, if an mRNA molecule becomes damaged and is missing a stop codon. In this scenario, prokaryotes use transfer-messenger RNA (tmRNA) to remedy this. Refer to Image 8 for the structure of tmRNA. Using it, answer the following questions. (a) (2 points) Looking at the structure of the tmRNA, what qualities make it similar to tRNA? What qualities make it similar to mRNA? Solution: The tmRNA has a D-loop, T-stem loop, and acceptor arm, all qualities found in tRNA (+1). The tmRNA has a single-stranded RNA region, similar to mRNA (+1). Page 19 of 33 Designer Genes MIT Science Olympiad (b) (2 points) It has also been found that, after tmRNA functions, the misread proteins are quickly proteolyzed by the prokaryotic cell. Given its similarities in structure to both tRNA and mRNA, propose a mechanism for tmRNA in resolving stalled ribosomes. Solution: The tmRNA enters the ribosomal site and adds its amino acid (+1), it is then translated on its own tmRNA ORF to finish translation (+1). (c) (2 points) Aminoglycosides such as streptomycin function by binding to ribosomal subunits, causing the ribosome to “misread” certain codons and incorrect translation to take place. In bacterial species that have upregulated tmRNA production, how do you expect them to respond to treatment with streptomycin? Why? Solution: Reduced responsiveness to streptomycin (+1) because tmRNA rescue cells are able to rescue stalled ribosomes and prevent nonfunctional protein accumulation (+1)

question: (17 points) VDJ recombination For this FRQ, we will be using the mechanism of VDJ recombination and its role in autoimmune disease as a framework. Principally, we will use the publications and works of Susumu Tonegawa (1987 Nobel prize in Medicine for discovery of the genetic principle for generation of antibody diversity and MIT professor) as primary inspiration. (a) Primarily, VDJ recombination represents a specialized class of recombination weaponized by the immune system. Let’s examine how VDJ recombination functions in the IgH locus. i. (2 points) Describe the sequence of recombination events that must occur to generate functional IgH. Why does D-J joining occur before V-D joining? ii. (2 points) The RAG1/RAG2 complex initiates VDJ recombination. Describe the 2-step cleavage mechanism employed by the RAG complex. (b) Tonegawa’s work revealed that antibody diversity arises from multiple mechanisms working in concert. i. (1 point) Calculate the theoretical combinatorial diversity possible from VDJ combination alone for IgH, given approximately 50 functional VH segments, 25 DH segments, and 6 JH segments. ii. (3 points) Explain how junctional diversity (N-region addition and P-nucleotide addition) dramatically in- creases antibody diversity beyond combinatorial diversity. Identity the enzyme responsible for N-region ad- dition and explain why this form of diversity is concentrated in CDR3 (complementarity-determining region
answer: (17 points) VDJ recombination For this FRQ, we will be using the mechanism of VDJ recombination and its role in autoimmune disease as a framework. Principally, we will use the publications and works of Susumu Tonegawa (1987 Nobel prize in Medicine for discovery of the genetic principle for generation of antibody diversity and MIT professor) as primary inspiration. (a) Primarily, VDJ recombination represents a specialized class of recombination weaponized by the immune system. Let’s examine how VDJ recombination functions in the IgH locus. i. (2 points) Describe the sequence of recombination events that must occur to generate functional IgH. Why does D-J joining occur before V-D joining? Solution: One D segments joined to one H segment, and V joins DJ complex (+1). The 12/23 rule dictates the order (D segments have 12-RSS on both sides, V and J both have 23. Thus V can’t join J, and D must serve as an intermediary) (+1). ii. (2 points) The RAG1/RAG2 complex initiates VDJ recombination. Describe the 2-step cleavage mechanism employed by the RAG complex. Solution: RAG introduces an ss-nick (+1), a hairpin loop forms (+1) (b) Tonegawa’s work revealed that antibody diversity arises from multiple mechanisms working in concert. i. (1 point) Calculate the theoretical combinatorial diversity possible from VDJ combination alone for IgH, given approximately 50 functional VH segments, 25 DH segments, and 6 JH segments. Solution: (50)(25)(6) = 7500 different heavy-chain combinations (+1) ii. (3 points) Explain how junctional diversity (N-region addition and P-nucleotide addition) dramatically in- creases antibody diversity beyond combinatorial diversity. Identity the enzyme responsible for N-region ad- dition and explain why this form of diversity is concentrated in CDR3 (complementarity-determining region

question: . (c) VDJ recombination is absolutely necessary for the function of the adaptive immune system. i. (1 point) Why does the adaptive immune system require such extensive receptor diversity? ii. (2 points) Patients with complete loss-of-function mutations in RAG1 or RAG2 develop severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Explain why T and B cells are absent but NK cells are present in these patients. (d) If VDJ recombination goes wrong, autoimmune diseases may result. As discussed by Bassing et. al. in their 2017 article, “it has been recognized for 40 years that the VDJ recombination-mediated assembly of diverse B and T lymphocyte antigen receptor (AgR) genes is not only essential for adaptive immunity, but also a risk for autoimmunity and lymphoid malignancies.” i. (1 point) RAG proteins introduce double-stranded breaks during VDJ recombination. Explain why AgR recombination must be tightly regulated to prevent genomic instability. (e) Hypomorphic mutations (mutations that reduce but don’t completely eliminate protein function) may lead to immunodeficiency and autoimmunity, especially in RAG1 and RAG2. i. (3 points) One condition this may lead to is Omenn syndrome, where T cells are present but exhibit autoim- munity, and B cells are absent. How might hypomorphic RAG mutations lead to Omenn syndrome? ii. (2 points) When looking at Omenn syndrome and SCID, how can two different loss-of-function mutations lead to two very different phenotypes? Note that we are specifically referring to the level of loss-of-function mutation.

question: Assume the effect of the down-promoter mutation is equivalent to and opposite in direction of the effect of CAP binding
answer: Assume the effect of the down-promoter mutation is equivalent to and opposite in direction of the effect of CAP binding lacZ- lacY- lacA- lacO- lacP- lacI- CAP site- Down-promoter mutation 0 0 1 1 0 1 0 Nonsense mutation in lacZ 0 1 1 1 0 1 0 lacZ- 0 1 1 1 0 1 0 Intergenic suppressor 1 1 1 1 Frameshift mutation in middle of lacY 1 0 1 1 0 1 0 Constitutively active lac repressor 0 0 0 1 0 0 0 Neutral mutation in lacY 1 1 1 1 1 1 1 Solution: See completed matrix above, each correct number is 0.5 pt, for a total of 46 ∗0.5 = 23pts Explanation: First, note that the method of “crossing” results in both lac operons present in the same cell. Also, note that lacA is not necessary for lactose catabolism. Following that, • Down-promoter mutations are found in promoter, cause a decrease in the rate of transcription (farther from consensus sequence). Effectively prevents transcription of operon. Expect none of the down-promoter strain to be expressed, but lacI works fine. • Nonsense mutation in lacZ is functionally equivalent to a lacZ- mutation, as the polycistronic mRNA nonsense doesn’t affect downstream start/stop codons • Intergenic suppressor mutation occurs in different gene, restores function • Frameshift mutation in middle of lacY makes lacY and lacA products nonfunctional • Constitutively active lac repressor causes no transcription even in presence of lactose Page 30 of 33 Designer Genes MIT Science Olympiad • Neutral mutation in lacY has functionally no change Easy points: • Last row must be all 1, because it is functionally like a wild type lac operon, and no mutations in the columns are trans-acting • Constitutively active lac repressor row must be all 0 except for lacO-, because it prevents transcription of all operons except in the case of lacO- where it cannot bind lac operon • lacO- column must be all 1, because the repressor is irrelevant when grown in a lactose medium • lacP- column must all be 0, because all mutations in the rows cause some form of nonfunctionality, and lacP- completely prevents transcription of otherwise functional structural genes, preventing any rescue of catabolism • lacI- column is all 1 except for constitutively active lac repressor because repressor is irrelevant when grown in a lactose medium • CAP site column is all 0 except for last row because no CAP bound causes no transcription

question: (17 points) Full gene expression tour For this FRQ, we’ll walk through each of transcription, translation, and post-translational modifications. E. coli will be our model organism. (a) To start, bacteria must recognize promoters and initiate transcription. i. (3 points) Describe the canonical bacterial promoter elements, including consensus sequences and positions relative to the TSS. What is the significance of the spacing between these elements? ii. (2 points) How does the bacterial sigma factor recognize and bind to promoter elements? (b) RNA polymerase then binds to the promoter and other related sequences. i. (2 points) Explain the structural transitions that occur as RNA polymerase moves from the closed complex to the open complex to the elongation complex. What happens to the sigma factor during this transition? ii. (2 points) The β’ subunit has a highly conserved metal-binding domain. What metal ion is coordinated, and how does it participate in RNA synthesis? (c) Termination is able to occur either intrinsically or extrinsically. i. (2 points) Explain the mechanism of ρ-independent termination. Is this extrinsic or intrinsic termination? ii. (2 points) Explain the mechanism of ρ-dependent termination. Is this extrinsic or intrinsic termination? (d) After termination, the mRNA makes its way to the ribosome and begins translation. i. (1 point) Why is the ribosome considered a ribozyme? ii. (1 point) During elongation, what is the role of EF-Tu? (e) After translation, post-translational modifications often take place. Prokaryotes lack many of the mechanisms that eukaryotes have, but some pathways still exist. i. (2 points) Protein acetylation is an important regulatory modification in bacteria. What are the functional consequences of this for protein stability and activity? Page 17 of 18 Designer Genes MIT Science Olympiad
answer: (17 points) Full gene expression tour For this FRQ, we’ll walk through each of transcription, translation, and post-translational modifications. E. coli will be our model organism. (a) To start, bacteria must recognize promoters and initiate transcription. i. (3 points) Describe the canonical bacterial promoter elements, including consensus sequences and positions relative to the TSS. What is the significance of the spacing between these elements? Solution: The -10 element (Pribnow box) is the consensus sequence TATAAT (+1). The -35 element is the consensus sequence TTGACA (+1). Spacing is 17 ± 1 bp, which allows them to be on the same face of the DNA helix and recognition by RNAP (+1). ii. (2 points) How does the bacterial sigma factor recognize and bind to promoter elements? Solution: Contains a consensus sequence for the promoter (+1). Aromatic amino acids in particular aid in destabilizing dsDNA (+1). (b) RNA polymerase then binds to the promoter and other related sequences. i. (2 points) Explain the structural transitions that occur as RNA polymerase moves from the closed complex to the open complex to the elongation complex. What happens to the sigma factor during this transition? Solution: Sigma factor is released from RNAP and is released from the transcription complex (+1). Other factors (such as NusA) compete for its former binding site (+1). ii. (2 points) The β’ subunit has a highly conserved metal-binding domain. What metal ion is coordinated, and how does it participate in RNA synthesis? Page 31 of 33 Designer Genes MIT Science Olympiad Solution: Mg2+ ions are required (+1). It stabilizes DNA when nucleotides are added (specifically for a nucleophilic attack) (+1). (c) Termination is able to occur either intrinsically or extrinsically. i. (2 points) Explain the mechanism of ρ-independent termination. Is this extrinsic or intrinsic termination? Solution: A hairpin loop forms, which destabilizes RNAP (+1). Intrinsic termination (+1). ii. (2 points) Explain the mechanism of ρ-dependent termination. Is this extrinsic or intrinsic termination? Solution: Rho forms a ring-like structure, which allows for the dissociation of RNA and DNA in the RNAP transcription complex (+1). Extrinsic (+1). (d) After termination, the mRNA makes its way to the ribosome and begins translation. i. (1 point) Why is the ribosome considered a ribozyme? Solution: rRNA catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds during translation (+1) ii. (1 point) During elongation, what is the role of EF-Tu? Solution: Helps to direct aminoacyl-tRNA to the acceptor site (A site) of the ribosome (+1) (e) After translation, post-translational modifications often take place. Prokaryotes lack many of the mechanisms that eukaryotes have, but some pathways still exist. i. (2 points) Protein acetylation is an important regulatory modification in bacteria. What are the functional consequences of this for protein stability and activity? Solution: May increase/decrease stability (+1). May increase/decrease activity (+1).

question: Actions and items (e.g., tools, notes, resources, supplies, electronics, etc.) are permitted, unless they are explicitly excluded in the rules, are unsafe, or violate the spirit of the problem.

While competing in an event, participants may not leave without the event supervisor’s approval and must not receive any external assistance. All electronic devices capable of external communication as well as calculator applications on multipurpose devices (e.g., laptop, phone, tablet) are not permitted unless expressly permitted in the event rule or by an event supervisor. Cell phones, if not permitted, must be turned off. At the discretion of the event supervisor, participants may be required to place their cell phones in a designated location.

Participants, coaches and other adults are responsible for ensuring that any applicable school or Science Olympiad policy, law, or regulation is not broken. All Science Olympiad content such as policies, requirements, rule corrections and rule clarifications on www.soinc.org must be treated as if it were included in the printed rules.

All pre-built devices presented for judging must be constructed, impounded, and operated by one or more of the 15 current team members unless stated otherwise in the rules. If a device has been removed from the event area, appeals related to that device will not be considered.

During the tournament, participants are only permitted to practice with any built or designed device at a Tournament event venue prior to competing if the Tournament Director makes the facilities open to all teams to practice.

DESCRIPTION: Participants will be assessed on their understanding of the anatomy and physiology for the nervous, special senses, and endocrine systems of the human body. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes CALCULATOR: Class II
EVENT PARAMETERS:

options.label: a
options.text: Each team may bring writing utensils.

options.label: b
options.text: Each team may bring two Class II calculators.

options.label: c
options.text: Each team may bring one (1) 8.5” x 11” sheet of paper that may contain information on both sides in any form and from any source. The sheet of paper may be laminated or placed in a sheet protector to increase durability. Affixed labels, as well as multiple sheets of paper (whether in a single sheet protector or not) are prohibited.

question: THE COMPETITION: This Event may be administered as a written test or as a series of lab-practical stations which can include but are not limited to experiments, scientific apparatus, models, illustrations, specimens, data collection and analysis, and problems for students to solve. Content topics will include:

options.label: a
options.text: Nervous System: All levels should understand: i. Cellular Anatomy & Physiology (1) Neurons: Understand the cellular anatomy and physiology of neurons, identify and understand synapses and neurotransmitters (2) Glial Cells: Compare the types of glial cells and their respective functions (3) Electrophysiology: qualitatively understand action potential generation and propagation in myelinated and unmyelinated neurons, and qualitatively & quantitatively understand models for the ionic basis of the cellular membrane potential (i.e. Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz voltage equation) ii. Central Nervous System (CNS) (1) The Brain: Understand the detailed structure and function of the cerebrum and its role in cognition, sensation, movement, memory, and language. Understand a general overview of structure and function of the cerebellum and brainstem (2) Spinal Cord: Understand a general overview of organization of the spinal cord and nerve roots. iii. Identification of simple encephalographic waveforms iv. Peripheral Nervous System – neural ganglia, action and physiology of sensory and motor neurons, organization of sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons, understand differences in and purposes of parasympathetic, sympathetic, somatic, and sensory systems, reflex arc physiology v. Disorders: Epilepsy, Alzheimer’s Disease, Multiple Sclerosis, Parkinson’s Disease, Cerebral Palsy, Stroke, Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) vi. Effects of the drugs: alcohol, caffeine, nicotine, and marijuana on the nervous system vii. Effect of toxins on neuron function and signaling (limited to tetrodotoxin, curare, botulinum toxin, anatoxin-a, and tetanus toxin) State & National Level Only: viii. The Brain: Understand the detailed structure and function of the brainstem and cerebellum, including specific nuclei clusters and tracts. ix. Cranial Nerves: Understand cranial nerve pathways, classification, and clinical assessments of their functions. x. Spinal Cord: Understand the detailed structure and function of the spinal cord, including specific ascending and descending tracts and their respective roles in sensation and motor function xi. General Senses: Understand the mechanisms for the general senses of touch, pressure, pain, temperature, itch, and proprioception and their relation to spinal cord tracts and the peripheral nervous system. National Level Only: xii. Electrophysiology: Understand the cable theory model of the neuron and modeling the neuron as a basic RC circuit, Quantitative models of the action potential (e.g. Hodgkin-Huxley model) and spiking neuron models ANATOMY & PHYSIOLOGY C ©2026 - C4 See General Rules, Eye Protection & other Policies on www.soinc.org as they apply to every event. C xiii. The Brain: Understand the detailed structure and function of the cerebral vasculature, including the internal carotid arteries, vertebral arteries, basilar artery, Circle of Willis, anterior cerebral artery (ACA), middle cerebral artery (MCA), posterior cerebral artery (PCA), superior cerebellar artery (SCA), anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA), and posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). xiv. Treatments and prevention for all conditions listed above (risk factors, medications, surgical treatment, etc.)

options.label: b
options.text: Special Senses: All levels should understand i. Anatomy and Physiology of Sight (1) Identify and describe the major parts of the eye: cornea, lens, iris, pupil, retina, optic nerve, and their functions. (2) Explain how light enters the eye and is focused on the retina, and the role of rods and cones in detecting light and color. ii. Anatomy and Physiology of Hearing and Balance (1) Identify the major parts of the ear: outer ear (pinna, ear canal), middle ear (eardrum, ossicles), inner ear (cochlea, semicircular canals) and their functions. (2) Describe how hair cells and the cochlea detect sound frequency and amplitude (3) Describe the semicircular canals and vestibular system in the inner ear and how they contribute to balance and spatial orientation. iii. Anatomy and Physiology of Smell (1) Identify the major structures involved in smell: the nasal cavity, olfactory epithelium, olfactory receptor cells, and olfactory bulb. (2) Describe how odor molecules bind to olfactory receptors in the nasal cavity, initiating the sense of smell. iv. Anatomy and Physiology of Taste (1) Identify the major structures involved in taste: tongue, taste buds, papillae, taste receptor cells, and gustatory nerves. v. Disorders: myopia, hyperopia, presbyopia, nyctalopia, astigmatism, conjunctivitis, color blindness, otitis externa, otitis media, types of deafness, anosmia/dysosmia, dysgeusia State & National Level Only: vi. Anatomy and Physiology of Sight (1) Explain the pathway of visual signal transmission from the retina through the optic nerve, optic chiasm, and optic tracts to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and visual cortex. (2) Describe how the visual fields are processed in each hemisphere of the brain and how damage at different points along this pathway (e.g., optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tract) can lead to specific visual field defects like monocular blindness, bitemporal hemianopia, or homonymous hemianopia. National Level Only: vii. Anatomy and Physiology of Sight (1) Describe the neural pathway involved in pupillary control, including the role of the pretectal nucleus, Edinger-Westphal nucleus, and oculomotor nerve in the pupillary light reflex. (2) Explain how light entering the eye triggers constriction of the pupil (miosis) through the parasympathetic system, and how dilation (mydriasis) occurs via the sympathetic pathway. viii. Diabetic Retinopathy, Macular Degeneration, Glaucoma, Otosclerosis, Presbycusis, Meniere’s Disease ix. Treatments and prevention for all conditions listed above (risk factors, medications, surgical treatment, etc.)

options.label: c
options.text: Endocrine System: all levels should understand i. Identify and compare and contrast three classes of hormones – steroids, peptides, and amines ii. Understand the mechanisms of hormone action – nuclear vs. cytoplasmic iii. Endocrine related problems – hypersecretion, hyposecretion, hypersensitivity, hyposensitivity iv. Identify, compare and contrast hormones and their respective functions secreted by the hypothalamus, pituitary gland, pineal gland, thyroid, parathyroid, thymus, adrenal glands, pancreas, and gonads v. Disorders: diabetes mellitus, central diabetes insipidus, hypoglycemia, hyperparathyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hyperthyroidism (including Graves’ disease), hypothyroidism (including Hashimoto’s disease), goiter, congenital iodine deficiency syndrome, primary hyperaldosteronism, polycystic ovary syndrome ANATOMY & PHYSIOLOGY C (CONT.) ©2026 - C5 See General Rules, Eye Protection & other Policies on www.soinc.org as they apply to every event. C State & National Level Only: vi. Identify hormones and their respective function secreted by additional organs (limited to the liver, kidneys, heart and adipose tissue) vii. Understand the exposure routes and effects of endocrine disruptors (limited to DDT, BPA, and PFAS) viii. Additional Disorders: Cushing’s Syndrome, Addison’s Disease, Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors ix. Endocrine cycles and negative feedback, Autonomic nervous system control of endocrine function National Level Only x. Explain the endocrine system's role in the stress response xi. Additional Disorders: Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia, Myxedema, acromegaly, and pituitary dwarfism xii. Treatments and prevention for all conditions listed above (risk factors, medications, surgical treatment, etc.)

question: DESCRIPTION: Teams will demonstrate an understanding of stellar evolution: From formation to destruction. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes CALCULATOR: Class IV

THE COMPETITION: Using information which may include Hertzsprung-Russell diagrams, spectra, light curves, motions, cosmological distance equations and relationships, stellar magnitudes and classification, multi-wavelength images (gamma-ray, X-ray, UV, optical, IR, radio), charts, graphs and JS9 imaging analysis tools, teams will compete in activities and answer questions related to:

options.label: a
options.text: Stellar evolution including stellar classification, spectral features and chemical composition, luminosity, blackbody radiation, spectroscopy, H-R diagram transitions, cold molecular clouds & star formation regions, protostars, T Tauri Variables, red giants, Mira variables, RR Lyrae variables, Cepheid variables, white dwarfs, planetary nebulas, neutron stars, pulsars, X-Ray binaries, and Type Ia and II supernovas.

options.label: b
options.text: Use orbital mechanics, Kepler’s laws, rotation and circular motion to answer questions relating to the orbital motions of binary and multiple star systems; use parallax, spectroscopic parallax, period- luminosity relations, and the distance modulus to calculate distances to RR Lyrae, Cepheids and Type Ia supernovas, and the Stefan-Boltzmann law to answer questions relating to the content areas outlined above.

options.label: c
options.text: Identify and answer questions relating to the content areas outlined above for the following objects: The Orion Molecular Cloud Complex, Sharpless 29 (NGC 6559), Ophion Star Family, HP Tau, Mira (Omicron Ceti), Helix Nebula (NGC 7293) Janus (ZTF J203349.8+322901.1), WDJ181058.67+311940.94, The Crab (M1), The Bone (G359.13), Cas A, Tycho’s SNR

question: SCORING: All questions will have been assigned a predetermined number of points. The highest score wins. Selected questions will be used to break ties. Recommended Resources: The Science Olympiad Store (store.soinc.org) carries a variety of resources to purchase; other resources are available on the Event Pages at soinc.org.
