question: DESCRIPTION: Each team will design one elastic cord to conduct drops at a given height(s) and attempt to get a mass placed in a bottle as close as possible to, but without touching, a landing surface. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 10 minutes EYE PROTECTION: B IMPOUND: Yes CALCULATOR: Class II
THE COMPETITION AREA:

options.label: a
options.text: Light and Heavy Mass: i. Supervisors will supply a light mass and a heavy mass that will each be composed of a 500-591 mL plastic bottle, mass inside of the bottle, and an attachment mechanism (hook, clasp, carabiner, etc.) that will connect the team’s bottom cord ring to the bottle. When hung, the masses including the attachment mechanism will have a height of at most 35.0 cm. ii. The light mass and heavy mass, individually, will be the same for all drops. iii. The light mass will have a total mass between 100.0 g and 300.0 g and be in increments of 25.0 g at regionals, 10.0 g at states, and 1.0 g at nationals. iv. The heavy mass will have a total mass between 200.0 g and 300.0 g heavier than the light mass, at increments of 1.0 g.

options.label: b
options.text: Drop Heights: i. At Regionals, there will be two total drops at one drop height, which will be between 2.00 and

question: 00 meters inclusive at an interval of 25.0 cm. ii. At States, there will be four total drops - two drops at each of two different drop heights. Both drop heights will be between 2.00 and 5.00 meters inclusive at an interval of 10.0 cm. iii. At Nationals there will be four total drops - two drops at each of two different drop heights. Both drop heights will be between 5.00 and 8.00 meters inclusive at an interval of 1.0 cm. iv. The Bonus Drop will be an additional single drop, trying to drop close to a Bonus Target Drop Distance (BTDD), rather than the landing surface. The BTDD must be greater than 2.00 m and less than the drop height (regionals) or larger drop height (states/nationals). v. The drop height will be measured from the bottom most point of the clamp/attachment portion at the top of the cord to the bottom landing surface. ©2026 - C13 See General Rules, Eye Protection & other Policies on www.soinc.org as they apply to every event. C BUNGEE DROP C (CONT.)

options.label: c
options.text: Supervisors must provide a top anchoring system/extended platform with a release mechanism (e.g., a clamp) to attach to the top end of the elastic cord. All teams must use this anchoring system.

options.label: d
options.text: Supervisors must provide an accurate system for determining how close a team’s device came to the landing surface, and whether or not it touched.

question: THE COMPETITION:

options.label: a
options.text: Teams will be given a total of 3 minutes to prepare their device in the holding area, followed immediately by 7 minutes to complete up to two drops at regionals and up to four drops at states and nationals as well as up to one bonus drop, if earned.

options.label: b
options.text: At States/Nationals, teams will perform two drops at the lower Drop Height first, then perform two drops at the higher Drop Height, followed by the Bonus Drop if eligible, which will be completed on the higher Drop Height.

options.label: c
options.text: Practice drops either in the competition area or within the vicinity of the competition area before or during competition are not allowed. Any drop, even if unintended or unannounced, will count as one of the drops allowed to the team.

options.label: d
options.text: A cord that is damaged during a drop will earn a Drop Score of 0.5x the total drop height and any remaining drops will be scored as incomplete.

options.label: e
options.text: The Heavy Mass Bonus. i. Teams can choose to attempt the heavy mass only on the 2nd drop for each drop height. If used, the heavy mass bonus earned will only apply to the drop(s) that used the heavy mass. ii. Teams that would like to attempt the heavy mass will attach the heavy mass (described in 5.a.) at the same closed ring as the 1st drop at each drop height, replacing the original light mass. f. The Bonus Drop. i. Teams with a drop score within the following parameters (30.0 pts at regionals, 20.0 pts at states,

question: DESCRIPTION: Teams will complete one or more tasks and answer a series of questions involving the science processes of chemistry focused in the areas of chemical reactions/stoichiometry and kinetics. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes EYE PROTECTION: C CALCULATOR: Class III
DESCRIPTION: Participants must complete tasks and answer questions about electricity and magnetism. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes CALCULATOR: Class III
THE COMPETITION: Part I: Written Test

options.label: a
options.text: The written test will assess the team’s knowledge of electricity and magnetism.

options.label: b
options.text: Unless otherwise requested, answers must be in metric units with appropriate significant figures.

options.label: c
options.text: The test will consist of at least one question from each of the following areas only: i. Properties of electric charges/fields, sources/hazards of static electricity, Coulomb’s Law, capacitance ii. Direct current (DC) characteristics, sources, uses, DC hazards iii. Alternating current (AC) characteristics, sources, uses, AC hazards, common household AC components iv. Concepts and units of current, voltage, resistance, power, energy, and using Ohm’s law v. Magnetic poles/fields, electromagnets, transformers, motors/generators, right-hand rule vi. Electrical control devices including switches, relays, fuses, ground fault circuit interrupters, and breakers vii. Simple calculations, constructions, and configurations of a circuit and individual components, including simple circuit diagrams viii. Simple circuit analysis using Kirchhoff’s Voltage & Current Laws ix. Historical perspective of the electricity and magnetism discoveries made by Ampere, Coulomb, Kirchhoff, Volta, Ohm, Tesla, & Faraday x. States/Nationals only: (1) Fundamental characteristics and operation of a light emitting diode (LED) (2) Basic electrical characteristics of silicon PN junctions (e.g., Diodes, PNP, NPN) (3) Basic operating principles and applications of Operational Amplifiers (op-amps)

options.label: d
options.text: Topics not included in the competition are: semiconductors (beyond those listed above), AC circuit theory, frequency analysis, inductance, calculations involving direct use of calculus and/or differential equations, non-linear devices, 3 Phase Power, and oscilloscopes. Part II: Hands-On Tasks

options.label: a
options.text: The hands-on portion will consist of at least one task for the teams to complete.

options.label: b
options.text: Participants must be familiar with the operation of breadboards and multimeters and how to use them. Participants may ask Event Supervisors for details of the internal wiring of any breadboards used for the tasks.

options.label: c
options.text: The hands-on tasks, or stations, may include but are not limited to: i. Determine the value of a mystery resistor in a circuit using only voltage measurements. ii. Calculate the power supplied to a circuit. iii. Given some wires, batteries, resistors, and 2 LEDs, hook them up so the LEDs are equally bright. iv. Construct an electromagnet using some wire, a bolt and battery. v. Given a USB charger, read the label and provide details of the various output power levels it can provide and calculate how long it would take to charge a specific battery.

question: DESCRIPTION: Teams will cryptanalyze and decode encrypted messages using cryptanalysis techniques for historical and modern advanced ciphers. A TEAM OF UP TO: 3 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes CALCULATOR: Class II

DESCRIPTION: Teams will answer questions, solve problems, and analyze data pertaining to classic, evolutionary, and molecular genetics. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes CALCULATOR: Class II

THE COMPETITION: This Event will be administered as a written test which may be arranged in stations. Questions will emphasize process skills such as quantitative reasoning, making calculations, analyzing and interpreting experimental results, and drawing evidence-based conclusions. The Event will cover topics listed below without overemphasis on any one particular topic. The list of topics and subtopics should be considered exhaustive.

options.label: a
options.text: For each of the following topics, participants will be expected to use quantitative reasoning and computational skills, analyze and interpret experimental results, and draw evidence-based conclusions. i. Mendelian Genetics (1) Describe Mendel’s Laws of Inheritance and their implications in heredity. Describe inheritance patterns which violate these laws (i.e. linkage, incomplete and codominance, complementation). (2) Use provided information to construct Punnett Squares of mono-, di- and trihybrid crosses. (3) Predict genotypes and phenotypes of offspring and compute their likelihood based on Punnett Squares and experimental data using probability rules. (4) Evaluate pedigrees to predict modes of inheritance (i.e. dominant vs recessive traits, autosomal vs sex-linked traits) and construct pedigrees based on data from a case study. (5) Understand epistasis and its implications in predicting genetic outcomes. (6) State and Nationals only: Map two (State) or three (National) genes on a chromosome based on recombination frequency data. ii. Mitosis and Meiosis (1) Understand, compare, and contrast the major stages and key structures in mitosis and meiosis. (2) Describe the effects of nondisjunction and use data from karyotypes to detect chromosomal abnormalities. (3) State and Nationals Only: Understand somatic recombination in the context of immune cell V(D)J recombination and immunoglobulin class switching. iii. Population & Evolutionary Genetics (1) Understand the assumptions and calculations that underlie the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium and the consequences of violating these assumptions. Be able to make these calculations given data. (2) Understand and explain the relationships between changing allele frequencies and genetic drift, founder effects, and bottlenecks, migration, and relative fitness. (3) Explain how additive alleles generate continuous variation and estimate the number of genes contributing to a trait. (4) Understand the role gene duplication plays in the evolution of the genome and new genes. Be able to identify homologs, orthologs, and paralogs. (5) Understand how a phylogenetic tree shows evolutionary histories and interpret phylogenies of nuclear, organellar, and extrachromosomal elements. Describe the basic steps of constructing a phylogenetic tree beginning with sequence data input. (6) State and Nationals only: Understand how heritability is used to explore phenotypic variation in a population. Calculate broad-sense heritability, narrow-sense heritability, and realized heritability. iv. Molecular Biology of DNA (1) Be able to identify and explain the components of DNA (i.e. structure of the nucleotides and backbone), directionality of DNA (5’ and 3’ ends), rules in the context of DNA structure and base pairing.

question: DESCRIPTION: Participants will use their investigative skills in the scientific study of disease, injury, health, and disability in populations or groups of people. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes CALCULATOR: Class II
DESCRIPTION: Teams will complete tasks related to physical and geological oceanography. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes CALCULATOR: Class II
THE COMPETITION: Participants will be tested over the following topics in the form of an exam and/or timed stations:

options.label: a
options.text: Seawater properties’ distributions and the processes affecting them: i. Temperature (e.g. thermocline, sea surface temperature) ii. Salinity (e.g. effect of water cycle, salt sources) iii. Pressure & density (e.g. three-layer model, stratification, mixing) iv. Other properties (e.g. nutrient concentrations, pH, chlorophyll)

options.label: b
options.text: Surface circulation: i. Warm and cool currents ii. Coriolis effect iii. Surface convergence and divergence iv. Western intensification v. Ekman transport vi. Eddies

options.label: c
options.text: Large-scale circulation: i. Thermohaline circulation ii. Global ocean energy transport iii. Water masses and fronts iv. Deep water formation

options.label: d
options.text: Waves: i. Wave types (e.g. wind waves, tsunamis, storm surge) & their formation ii. Wave interaction with coasts (e.g. surf, wave shoaling) iii. Related properties, including but not limited to wave velocity, wave height, wavelength, period, and fetch

options.label: e
options.text: Tides: i. Diurnal/semidiurnal/mixed patterns ii. Spring/neap tides iii. Resonance iv. Tidal currents f. Coastal features and processes: i. Estuaries ii. Coastal erosional and depositional landforms iii. Formations of coral reefs; atolls iv. Longshore currents, rip currents v. Coastal upwelling and downwelling g. Geological oceanography: i. Tectonic processes in ocean basins (e.g. seafloor spreading and associated evidence, oceanic crust composition and evolution) ii. Ocean floor features (e.g. ridges, seamounts, trenches, continental rise/slope/shelf) iii. Oceanic sediment (e.g. sediment types, turbidity currents/turbidites, abyssal plains) h. Climate variability and change: i. Atmosphere/ocean variability, limited to El Niño Southern Oscillation, Pacific Decadal Oscillation, Southern Annular Mode ii. Ocean climate change effects (e.g. sea level rise, thermal expansion, coastal flooding, acidification, deoxygenation) ©2026 - C25 See General Rules, Eye Protection & other Policies on www.soinc.org as they apply to every event. C i. Oceanic tools used for research (e.g. water samples, sediment cores, seawater velocity trackers, sonar and acoustic sensing, CTD devices) j. Pressure-gradient force, geostrophic balance, Rossby waves, Kelvin waves

DESCRIPTION: Prior to the tournament, teams will construct, collect data on test flights, analyze and optimize free flight rubber-powered helicopters to achieve maximum time aloft. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 15 minutes
FLIGHT LOGS:

options.label: a
options.text: Teams may present a Flight Log of recorded data for a BONUS. This data must include 6 or more parameters (3 required and at least 3 additional) with data for 10 or more test flights prior to the competition. i. The required parameters are: (1) Motor Size before wind-up (2) Number of Turns on Launch or Torque at Launch (3) Flight Time ii. The team must choose 3 additional data parameters beyond those required (e.g. turns remaining at landing, estimated/recorded peak flight altitude, the motor torque at landing, propeller pitch, etc.)

options.label: b
options.text: All numeric data must include units which may be listed with the column headers of the log. Torque units may be “arbitrary” if an uncalibrated torque meter with arbitrary numbers is utilized.

options.label: c

question: DESCRIPTION: Prior to the competition, participants will design, construct, and calibrate a self-propelled air-levitated vehicle that moves down a track. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 10 minutes EYE PROTECTION: B IMPOUND: Yes CALCULATOR: Class III
THE TRACK:

options.label: a
options.text: The Event Supervisor will supply a 45.0 ± 0.5 cm wide and at least 240 cm long track on a non-carpeted smooth floor or other firm smooth base surface, such as a countertop or large board. The outside boundary of the track is composed of rails each with a height at least 30.0 mm (standard 2x4 framing studs or steel framing studs recommended). The Event Supervisor will also supply a cushioned barrier to stop vehicles and a wood block to hold the vehicle at the start line. Example setups are at www.soinc.org. ©2026 - C43 See General Rules, Eye Protection & other Policies on www.soinc.org as they apply to every event. C

options.label: b
options.text: Each rail must be securely affixed to the floor, base, or each other.

options.label: c
options.text: The length of the timed portion of the track is fixed at 185.0 ± 0.5 cm. A start line must be marked that is at least 45.0 cm from the end of the track. The finish line must be marked 185.0 ± 0.5 cm from the start line and a cushioned barrier at least 5.0 cm past it must block the channel.

options.label: d
options.text: A photogate timing system is highly recommended. If used, the system will be installed at the start and finish lines with the beams at a height of 17.0 ± 2.0 cm. At least one manual timer should be used as a backup. If photogates are not being used, three timekeepers should be utilized with the median time used as the official Run Time; lasers are recommended to be placed at the start and finish lines so the timekeepers only have to watch for the flash of light as the dowel cuts through the laser beam. Time is recorded in seconds to the device precision if photogates are used, or to the tenth of a second if manual timers are used.

options.label: e
options.text: The Event Supervisor must provide a removable ramp that competitors may use for the launching of their vehicle. The ramp should have a smooth, flat surface and must span the width of the track between the rails. The height of the ramp is 5.0 ± 0.5 cm and the length of the ramp’s surface is 41.0 ± 0.5 cm. When the ramp is placed on the track, the edge where the vehicle exits the ramp must be 4.0 ±

question: DESCRIPTION: Teams will complete lab activities and answer a series of questions related to the materials science of nanomaterials with an emphasis on chemical, physical, optical, and mechanical properties of nanomaterials. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes EYE PROTECTION: C CALCULATOR: Class III
THE COMPETITION: Part 1: Lab Activity

options.label: a
options.text: At least one lab activity must be performed. Refer to soinc.org for a list of core competencies for chemistry events. Topics for lab activities shall be consistent with topics listed under Part 2: Written Test

options.label: b
options.text: Lab Activities will comprise at least 15% of the total score at the Regional Level, 25% at the State Level, and 35% at the National Level. Part 2: Written Test

options.label: a
options.text: The written test will focus on the chemical structure, crystalline structure, characterization, performance, synthesis, processing and applications of nanomaterials.

options.label: b
options.text: Types and applications of nanomaterials: Metal nanomaterial, metal-oxide nanomaterials, ceramic nanomaterials, semiconductor nanomaterials, carbon-based nanomaterials (graphene, fullerenes, nanotubes, etc); zero dimensional, one dimensional, two dimensional, and three-dimensional nanomaterials; nanofluids. Uses of the types of nanomaterials. The following nanomaterials are NOT included: polymer nanomaterials, organic nanomaterials.

options.label: c
options.text: Structure: Crystalline structure, amorphous nanomaterials, interatomic bonding, intermolecular forces, size effects of nanomaterials, Grain boundaries. State and National levels only may include: Diffusion, crystalline defects.

options.label: d
options.text: Chemistry of surfaces: Surface area/volume ratio, surface energy, surface tension, wetting angle, hydrophobicity, hydrophilicity, surfactants.

options.label: e
options.text: Nanomaterials synthesis and fabrication: Top-down synthesis techniques (e.g., milling, sputtering, chemical etching, lithography, etc.) and Bottom-up synthesis techniques (e.g., sol-gel process, chemical vapor deposition, self-assembly, molecular beam epitaxy, etc.) f. Characterization: X-ray diffraction, light and electron microscopes, scanning probe microscopy, spectroscopes (e.g., UV-visible, photoluminescence, energy dispersive, mass, etc.) g. Physical & Mechanical properties: Melting temperature, density, hardness, strength, elastic modulus, calculation of stress, strain, and elastic modulus, adhesion, wear. h. Optical properties: Scattering, absorption, color, reflection, refraction, transmission. State and National levels only may include Luminescence, fluorescence, plasmons, quantum confinement effects on optical properties. i. Thermal, Electrical, & Magnetic properties: Thermal conductivity, Electrical conductivity, electronic band structure, surface scattering, dielectric properties, semiconductor behavior. State and National levels only may include Magnetic fields, saturation magnetization, types of magnetism in nanomaterials, quantum confinement effects on electrical properties.

question: SCORING: High score wins.

options.label: a
options.text: Lab Activities (at least 15% at Regional, 25% at State, and 35% at National)

options.label: b
options.text: Written Test (No more than 85% at Regional, 75% at State, and 65% at National)

options.label: c
options.text: Ties will be broken by pre-selected questions. question: DESCRIPTION: Participants will use remote sensing imagery, data, and computational process skills to complete tasks related to climate change processes in the Earth system. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes CALCULATOR: Class II

DESCRIPTION: Teams design, build, program and test one Robotic Vehicle to navigate a track to reach a target at a set amount of time as accurately and efficiently as possible. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 18 minutes IMPOUND: Yes

DESCRIPTION: Teams will identify and classify rocks and minerals and demonstrate knowledge of how rocks and minerals help to understand geologic processes, interpretation of earth’s history, the development of natural resources, and use by society. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes CALCULATOR: Class II
For identification purposes, information will be provided such as diagnostic properties, chemical formulas, grain size, or composition.
The pink/tan variety of feldspar should be identified as Orthoclase/Microcline or Potassium feldspar.
Although Tourmaline is the generic name for a group of related mineral species, for identification purposes, tourmaline will be accepted.
Bauxite has been reclassified as a sedimentary rock.
Rock Salt and Rock Gypsum for identification purposes are considered the same, respectively, as the minerals Halite and Gypsum and do not need to be distinguished

DESCRIPTION: Participants will be assessed on their understanding and evaluation of freshwater aquatic environments. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes EYE PROTECTION: C CALCULATOR: Class II

THE COMPETITION: This may include analysis, interpretation or use of charts, graphs and sample data. Supervisors are expected to utilize freshwater scenarios and have students analyze and evaluate comparative macroinvertebrates and water quality data. Process skills may include equipment use, collecting and interpreting data, measuring, analyzing data, and making inferences. Part I: Freshwater Ecology – 30% of the total score

options.label: a
options.text: This section will use multiple choice, matching, fill-in-the-blank and/or short answer questions in areas such as: aquatic ecology, water cycle, nutrient cycling, aquatic chemistry and its implications for life, potable water treatment, waste water treatment, aquatic food chains/webs, community interactions, population dynamics, watershed resource management issues, sedimentation pollution, and harmful species.

options.label: b
options.text: Understand and apply the concept of indigenous knowledge or traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) to given scenarios.

options.label: c
options.text: State and Nationals only: life history strategies (e.g.; age structure, survival curves, life tables, succession, R and K strategies). Part II: Freshwater Macroinvertebrates – 30% of the total score

options.label: a
options.text: This section will require participants to identify (common name only) immature and adult macroinvertebrates and aquatic nuisance organisms listed below and to understand their importance as indicators of water and wetland quality.

options.label: b
options.text: In addition, teams are expected to know the general ecology, life cycles, and feeding habits of all listed organisms: Class 1 – Pollution Sensitive Class 2 – Moderately Sensitive Class 3 – Moderately Tolerant Class 4 – Pollution Tolerant Class 5 – Air Breathing Mayfly Aquatic Sowbug Water Mite Air Breathing Snail Whirligig Beetle Caddisfly Damselfly Midge Deer/Horse Fly Water Strider Stonefly Dragonfly Blackfly Tubifex Mosquito Dobsonfly Scuds Flatworm Blood Midge Giant Water Bug Gilled Snails Crane Fly Leeches Back Swimmer Water Penny Water Boatman Riffle Beetle Predacious Diving Beetle Water Scorpion Aquatic Nuisance Plants: Purple Loosestrife, Eurasian Water Milfoil, and Water Hyacinth Aquatic Nuisance Animals: Zebra Mussel, Spiny Water Flea, Asian Tiger Mosquito, Asian Carp and Crayfish/Crawdads

question: DESCRIPTION: Participants will demonstrate their knowledge of plant life and general botany principles. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes CALCULATOR: Class II
SAMPLE QUESTIONS/TASKS:

options.label: a
options.text: What leaf structure is being shown on this microscope slide?

options.label: b
options.text: Using the graph, identify the peak wavelength for chlorophyll absorbance.

options.label: c
options.text: Identify three key differences between flowering plants and ferns.

options.label: d
options.text: Which plants would be in the next wave of plant succession for the region shown?

options.label: e
options.text: Describe the role plants play in the nitrogen cycle.

question: DESCRIPTION: Participants will participate in three quiz and coding activities designed to assess their knowledge of practice module material in four areas: programming concepts, AI, cryptography and Python. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes

DESCRIPTION: Prior to the tournament, teams will design, build, and bring up to two bottle rockets to the tournament to launch a ping pong ball attached to a parachute to stay aloft for the greatest amount of time. A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 5 minutes EYE PROTECTION: B
PRACTICE LOG:

options.label: a
options.text: During inspection, each team must present a flight log of recorded data for each rocket. Data must include 5 or more parameters (3 required and at least 2 additional) for 15 or more test flights prior to the competition for each rocket. The required parameters are: 1) pressure (psi), 2) estimated/recorded peak flight height (feet), 3) time aloft (seconds). The additional parameters are chosen by the team (examples include: # fins, parachute diameter, etc.)

options.label: b
options.text: Teams must use their data to justify their pressure choice. Rockets without a flight log or an incomplete log will NOT be launched.

question: DESCRIPTION: Participants will use computer visualization and online resources to construct a physical model of a de novo designed ideal protein structure. This year's event will focus on DI-II_10 as described in doi: 10.1038/nature1, paper freely available at https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3705962/ A TEAM OF UP TO: 2 APPROXIMATE TIME: 50 minutes IMPOUND: Yes
THE COMPETITION: Part I: The Pre-Built Model

options.label: a
options.text: Participants will use the program JUDE (Jmol User Design Environment) to visualize residues 1 – 100 of DI-II_10 based on data found in the 2LV8 file. The atomic coordinate data file can be accessed for free from the RCSB Protein Data Bank (www.rcsb.org). A constructed model of this protein must be brought to all competitions; as the competition level increases, the scoring rubrics for the pre-built model will reflect higher expectations for model accuracy, detail, and enhancements. (See SCORING for more details.) JUDE can be accessed at learn.3dmoleculardesigns.com/digital-modeling-hub/jude_online_ jmol for free.

options.label: b
options.text: The pre-built model must be based on the protein's alpha carbon backbone display, using a scale of 2 cm per amino acid. Students may manually fold their pre-built model using Modeling Ties or comparable bendable material (Mini-Toobers, Kwik Twists, 12-gauge dimensional house wire, etc.). The backbone should primarily be gray with a diameter of 0.75 – 1.25 cm.

options.label: c
options.text: Three-dimensional (3D) printed materials may NOT be used to build the protein backbone but may be used for functionally relevant features.

options.label: d
options.text: Participants will use materials of their choosing to add functionally relevant features to their model (e.g., selected amino acid sidechains, DNA, or associated molecules). These additions should highlight the significance of structure to the protein's function.

options.label: e
options.text: When an amino acid sidechain is displayed, its chemical property should be annotated on the alpha- carbon of the backbone. For example, hydrophobic sidechains are yellow, hydrophilic white, acidic red, basic blue, and cysteine green. f. Participants must explain their functionally relevant features using clear and concise descriptions on a printed 4.25" x 5.5" paper, in the form of a table with 3 columns, headed: i. What is displayed? ii. How is it displayed? iii. Why is it displayed? g. All models, including all functionally relevant features, must fit within a 50.0 cm x 50.0 cm x 50.0 cm space. h. The model must be sufficiently sturdy so that judges can remove it from any scaffolding or support, pick it up, and rotate it so that they can view it unobstructed from any angle and properly evaluate it. i. Teams must deliver their pre-built model and Model Description Legend for impounding. They may pick up pre-built models after the competition. Part II: Written Exam

options.label: a
options.text: Teams will complete a written exam to assess their protein structure and function knowledge and their ability to explore protein structures in the molecular visualization environment, JUDE. The exam will consist of multiple-choice and short-answer questions.

question: A group of scientists is engineering a bacterial strain to control production of a synthetic enzyme, SigmaRizz47, by modifying its gene’s regulatory architecture. They are considering features borrowed from natural systems such as the lac operon and the trp operon.

options.label: a

options.label: b

question: A molecular biology lab is investigating whether a rare bacterial pathogen is present in a water sample from a nearby lake. The pathogen’s DNA is only present in very small amounts, making it difficult to detect with direct methods. The scientists decide to use the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to amplify a specific gene unique to this bacterium.

options.label: a
options.text: Describe what happens during the denaturation step of PCR. Why is a high temperature required at this stage? (2 pt)

options.label: b
options.text: Explain what occurs during the annealing step of PCR. How do primers determine the specificity of amplification? (2 pt)

options.label: c
options.text: During the extension step, DNA polymerase plays a critical role. Identify the enzyme typically used in PCR, explain why it is chosen, and describe how it functions at this stage. (2 pt)

options.label: d
options.text: PCR relies on precise temperature cycling. Explain how the differences in optimal temperature for each step (denaturation, annealing, extension) reflect the molecular events occurring at the DNA level. (3 pt)

options.label: e
options.text: PCR can be used to answer many experimental questions. Propose two distinct research applications of PCR (other than pathogen detection), and for each, explain what information PCR provides that would not be easily obtained without it. (4 pt) f. Imagine that the water sample contains many closely related bacterial species with DNA sequences that differ only by a few bases. The scientists design primers that are not perfectly specific. Predict how this would affect the PCR results. Suggest one experimental modification that could improve specificity. Explain the molecular reasoning behind your suggestion. (3 pt) QUESTION 11: FOUNDER FLOUNDER

options.label: a
options.text: What a beautiful island of pentagons! On this island, let the black color phenotype be BB and the white color phenotype be bb. As you can see, there is a third phenotype on the island. i. Billy says that it seems like the third phenotype is a mixture of the white and black phenotype…What term is used to describe this? (1pt) ii. Beatrissa says that it seems like the third phenotype expresses both the white and black phenotype…What term is used to describe this? (1pt)

answer: You are studying two human cell lines. One has a defect in BRCA1, while the other has a defect in Ku70/Ku80. Which outcome best describes the repair defects expected in these cells? a. Both cell lines are unable to repair UV-induced thymine dimers. b. The BRCA1-deficient cells are impaired in homologous recombination, while the Ku-deficient cells are impaired in non-homologous end joining. c. The BRCA1-deficient cells fail in mismatch repair, while the Ku-deficient cells fail in base excision repair. d. Both cell lines can still repair double-strand breaks accurately because DNA ligase I can compensate.

question: Give one experimental question that could realistically be addressed by Sanger sequencing, and explain why Sanger sequencing is more suitable for this than next-gen sequencing or PCR. (3 pt) QUESTION 13: NEXT/THIRD GEN SEQUENCING
answer: Give one experimental question that could realistically be addressed by Sanger sequencing, and explain why Sanger sequencing is more suitable for this than next-gen sequencing or PCR. (3 pt) One example:verifying the precise sequence of a clonedgenebefore using it in experiments.(1 pt) Sanger is more suitable here than PCR or next-gen sequencing because it provideshighly accurate reads of a single DNA fragmentover ~500–1000bp, which is ideal for confirming plasmid constructs.(1 pt) Next-gen sequencing is better for high-throughput but less efficient/cost-effective for a single gene, while PCR only amplifies DNA but does not provide base-by-base sequence information.(1 pt) QUESTION 13: NEXT/THIRD GEN SEQUENCING

question: A team of scientists is investigating how mammalian cells progress through the cell cycle. They are focusing on the role of cyclins, CDKs, and checkpoint mechanisms that maintain genome stability.

options.label: a
options.text: Identify the phases of the eukaryotic cell cycle in the correct order. For each of the interphase stages (G1, S, G2), describe the key cellular events that occur. (4 pt)

options.label: b
options.text: Cyclins and CDKs are central regulators of the cell cycle. Explain how cyclin concentrations fluctuate during the cycle, and why CDK activity depends on these fluctuations. (3 pt)

options.label: c
options.text: Describe the molecular events at the G1/S checkpoint (restriction point). Which signals or conditions must be satisfied for the cell to commit to DNA replication? (3 pt)

options.label: d
options.text: The G2/M checkpoint ensures accurate chromosome segregation. Explain how this checkpoint prevents mitotic entry if DNA damage or replication errors are present. In your answer, mention the role of p53 and Cdc25. (4 pt)

options.label: e
options.text: Researchers engineer cells that overexpress cyclin D. Predict how this alteration would affect progression through the cell cycle, particularly at the G1/S transition. Discuss how this could contribute to oncogenesis. (4 pt) f. A drug is discovered that inhibits APC/C activity. At which stage of mitosis would the cell arrest? Explain the role of APC/C in cyclin degradation and sister chromatid separation. (4 pt) g. Compare and contrast the DNA damage checkpoint and the spindle assembly checkpoint (SAC) in terms of: i. What each monitors (2 pt) ii. The molecular mechanisms involved (at least one protein example each) (2 pt) iii. The consequences if the checkpoint fails (1 pt) MULTIPLE CHOICE & SHORT ANSWER

question: Why might it be advantageous for an organism to have GC-rich regions in its genome? Provide at least one advantage, and connect it to a specific biological context (e.g., replication, transcription, or adaptation to environment). (2 pts)
answer: Why might it be advantageous for an organism to have GC-rich regions in its genome? Provide at least one advantage, and connect it to a specific biological context (e.g., replication, transcription, or adaptation to environment). (2 pts) GC base pairs form three hydrogen bonds compared to the two bonds in AT base pairs. This makes GC-rich DNA regions more thermally stable and harder to denature.(1 pt)In certain biological contexts, such as organisms living at high temperatures (thermophiles), GC-rich regions provide greater DNA stability and reduce the risk of strand separation. GC-rich promoters can also influence transcription regulation, creating stable structures that affect gene expression.(1 pt)

When an allele that is neutral or even slightly harmful increases in frequency in a population not because it is under selection itself, but because it is located near a beneficial allele that is undergoing a selective sweep

question: Describe two different ways in which RNA polymerase is terminated from continuing to code for mRNA.( 2 points)
answer: Describe two different ways in which RNA polymerase is terminated from continuing to code for mRNA.( 2 points) One point is awarded [max 2 points] for each correctly identified answer of the following: ● The DNA sequence codes for a “hairpin” in the mRNA that encourages the RNA polymerase to detach ● A specific sequence in the DNA is recognized by the RNA polymerase, encouraging it to be removed from the DNA ● (in the case of RNA polymerase II), the remaining (unused) RNA is cleaved and degraded from the main strand ■ Note: RNA Polymerase II does not need to be directly stated for a point to be awarded for this answer ● (in the case of RNA polymerase I and III), termination factors bind to the enzyme and signal termination ■ Note: Neither RNA polymerase I nor III need to be directly stated for a point to be awarded for this answer

question: (a) (4 points) What are four conditions to Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium? Consider a population of pea plants with purple and white ﬂowers, with purple ﬂowers being dominant to white ﬂowers, where 11% of plants have white ﬂowers. Assume this population is in Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium (b) (3 points) What is the frequency of each allele? (c) (3 points) What is the frequency of purple ﬂowers in the population, and what proportion of purple ﬂowered plants are heterozygous? (TB) (d) (2 points) If pollinators favored the less common phenotypes (e.g. when there are more purple ﬂowers, they pollinate white ﬂowers more frequently and vice versa), what type of selection is this most emblematic of? (e) (3 points) If a serious drought occurred and only 5 individuals in the population survived, then how would the genetic diversity of the population change? What e!ect is this an example of? Let’s now consider how the population might change if the di!erent genotypes had di!erent ﬁtnesses. In our scenario, purple ﬂowered heterozygous plants are the most ﬁt (relative ﬁtness of 1.0), while white ﬂowered plants are less ﬁt (relative ﬁtness of 0.6) and purple ﬂowered homozygous plants even less so (relative ﬁtness of 0.4). (f) (2 points) Which genotype has the highest proportion of its individuals survive and reproduce? What is this phenomenon called where this genotype has the highest proportion of survival and reproduction? (g) (4 points) What is the mean ﬁtness of the population given that there are still 11% of individuals with white ﬂowers? (h) (3 points) After one generation, what proportion of the population is heterozygous? (TB) (i) (1 point) After an indeﬁnitely long amount of time, which genotype would be most common? (j) (2 points) Why isn’t the long run mean ﬁtness equal to 1.0? Page 5 of 8 Designer Genes
source: 2026 SOAPS B-C_Designer Genes C Test Packet.pdf

question: For this question, treat capital letters as dominant alleles and lowercase letters as recessive alleles. Let one parent plant have the genotype AaBbCcddEE and the other have the genotype AaBbccDdEE. Assume that these genes are not linked, independent, and inherited through simple Mendelian genetics. (a) (2 points) What is the probability of o!spring having the genotype AabbCCddEe? (b) (2 points) What is the probability of o!spring having the genotype AABBccddEE? (c) (2 points) What is the probability of o!spring having the genotype AaBbCcddEE? Now, imagine that all of the genes contribute to the same trait, the height of o!spring, with each gene expressing the dominant phenotype adding a certain amount to the height. For example, aabbccddee will have the minimum height, and AaBBCCDdEe would have the maximum height. (d) (2 points) What is the name for this type of inheritance? (e) (2 points) Given that there are 5 di!erent genes, how many di!erent possible heights exist if each allele contributes the same amount? This includes o!spring that cannot be produced in a cross between these parents. (f) (3 points) If each gene contributes 1 unit of height, what is the probability that a cross between two parents with genotypes AaBbCcDdEe and aabbccddee results in a child with height 3 units. (g) (5 points) Now, again assuming that each gene contributes 1 unit of height, what is the probability that the two parents from the start of this problem have a child with the lowest possible height for these parents? What is this lowest possible height, assuming that the minimum possible height is 0 and each dominant gene adds 1 to the height? The eye color of D. melanogaster is controlled by many genes. The scarlet gene (S) produces scarlet pigment, the brown gene (B) produces brown pigment, and the white gene (W) transports these pigments to the eye. For each of these genes, the functional, wildtype version of the gene is dominant to the inactive, mutant versions. Additionally, the white gene is sex-linked. Ordinarily, both brown and scarlet pigments are transported to the eye and the eyes are red. If only one pigment is present, then that single pigment determines the eye color. If pigments are not present in the eye at all, either due to lack of pigment production or lack of transport, then the eye is white. Consider the cross between a female with the genotype SsBbWw and a male with the genotype ssBbWY. Assume that the three genes are inherited independent of one another. (2) Fill in the Punnett Square representing the inheritance of the white gene for this cross. (3) Fill in the Punnett Square representing the inheritance of the brown and scarlet genes for this cross. (2) What proportion of the progeny will be homozygous recessive for the brown gene? (4) What proportion of the progeny will have white eyes? (1) What genetic phenomenon best describes the relationship between the white gene and the brown and scarlet genes?

(2) A cross between true-breeding strains of the largest and smallest possible varieties yields 1054 F2 progeny when intercrossing the F1 generation. How many progeny do you expect to have the smallest body size? Assume that these genes inherit independently from one another.

question: Metaphase II
answer: 2 POINTS Immediately after duplication, the two identical paralogs perform the same function, providing a redundant backup system. Because the original, essential function is maintained by the first copy, the second copy serves as a “backup copy” and thus are not immediately harmful. Most mutations will lead to a loss of function (pseudogenization), but sometimes, a mutation will be advantageous and natural selection acts to retain both copies in the genome: one performing the original function and the other the new function, increasing the organism's overall fitness and genetic complexity.

question: In mice, the agouti gene controls variations in color. There are 17 alleles of the agouti gene. One of the alleles, lethal yellow (Ay), is dominant over the nonagouti allele (a) and causes the mouse to have yellow fur and obesity. Homozygous lethal yellow is lethal early in development. (a) (8) A mature female mouse with lethal yellow coloring is crossed with a non-agouti (wildtype) male mouse. Fill in the Punnett square below to show the possible genotypes for the resulting offspring. Image from: https://www.kamiapp.com/library/resources/66k6uGj1GVby-punnett-square (b) (3) If there are three pups in the litter, what is the probability that all three are heterozygous? Show all work. (c) (3) Lethal yellow offspring can be rescued in utero by feeding the dam a diet supplemented with methyl group-rich compounds. How is this possible? (d) (4) Suppose a scientist wants to study the process described in the previous question that allows for lethal yellow mice’s offspring to display the wildtype phenotype. What would be the best way to precisely knockout a heterozygous offspring’s Ay allele? Briefly explain why you chose this technique. answer: (a) (8 pts.) Image from: https://www.kamiapp.com/library/resources/66k6uGj1GVby-punnett-square Solution: From left to right, by rows (if male is top row): a a Ay Aya Aya a aa aa (1pt. for each space filled in correctly) (accept other orientation with female in top row) (b) (3 pts.) Solution: Probability of one mouse being Aya: 2/4 = 0.5 (1pt. for correct probabil- ity) Probability of 3 mice being Aya: 0.5∗0.5∗0.5 = 0.125 or 0.53 = 0.125 (1pt. for correct equation) (1pt. for correct answer) Team Number: Points earned: 2025 UT Invitational Page 3 of 19 Designer Genes C Answer Sheet (c) (3 pts.) Solution: Methyl groups from the mother’s enriched diet causing DNA methylation in the pups in utero, repressing the lethal yellow allele (1pt. for DNA methylation) (1pt. for methyl groups from mother’s diet) (1pt. for lethal yellow/agouti repression) **Do NOT accept ”epigenetic changes”** (d) (4 pts.) Solution: CRISPR or TALENs (3pts.) because of ability to carry out high precision KO (1pt. for correct reason why)

question: Two inbred lines of peas were intercrossed; the variance in pod length among F1 was 2mm. The F1 offspring were intercrossed; the variance in pod length in F2 was 7mm. (a) (5) Calculate the broad-sense heritability of pod length in the F2 population of peas. (b) (4) Interpret the h2 you calculated in the previous part.
answer: (a) (5 pts.) Solution: H2 = σ2G/σ2P (1pt. correct formula used) σ2P = 7 (1pt.), σ2E = 2 (1pt.), σ2G = 5 (1pt.) 5/7 = H2 = 0.71 (1pt. correct answer) (b) (4 pts.) Solution: 71% of the phenotypic variation in pea pod length is due to genetic vari- ance among individuals. (2pts.) 29% of the observed phenotypic differences in pea pod length are due to environ- mental sources of variation. (2pts.)

question: Law of Independent Assortment ___
Law of Segregation ___
For pea plants, flower color and pea color are often inherited together, with offspring typically having the same combination of flower and pea color of their parents. (2pts)
answer: For pea plants, flower color and pea color are often inherited together, with offspring typically having the same combination of flower and pea color of their parents. Law of Independent Assortment (1) is violated; two separate traits are inherited together, not independently.

question: Which is often more harmful, nondisjunction during meiosis I or meiosis II? Briefly explain why. (4pts)
answer: Which is often more harmful, nondisjunction during meiosis I or meiosis II? Briefly explain why. question: Why might immune cells want V(D)J recombination to each express a unique receptor? (2pts) Team Number ________ Pg. 5 Team Name __________________________ Section 3: Population and Evolutionary Genetics (41 points): Answer the following multiple choice questions (20 pts total):
answer: Why might immune cells want V(D)J recombination to each express a unique receptor? If each immune cell expresses a unique receptor, then each cell will be able to detect and respond to a unique pathogen, allowing for the pathogen coverage of the immune system to be incredibly diverse. answer: In which stage of transcription (initiation, elongation, termination) is the process different between Rho-dependent and Rho-independent transcription? Briefly contrast the differences in that step. Termination (1 point). Rho-dependent: requires rho protein to RNA to dislodge RNA polymerase, ending transcription (2 points). question: Both the lac operon and trp operon both have repressors. Briefly contrast how, under normal conditions, the repressor operates. (5pts
answer: Both the lac operon and trp operon both have repressors. Briefly contrast how, under normal conditions, the repressor operates. The LacI repressor is active by default and binds the operator to block transcription when lactose is absent. Regulated by inactivating the repressor (2.5 points). Trp operon: The TrpR repressor is inactive by default and only binds the operator when tryptophan is abundant, repressing transcription (2.5 points).

Ubiquitin-mediated disassembly of the CMG helicase complex to terminate fork progression Exchange of the replicative polymerase for specialized translesion polymerases to allow synthesis past the lesion site Recruitment of global genomic nucleotide excision repair factors to remove bulky adducts ahead of the fork Polyubiquitin-dependent signaling for template switching and homologous recombination repair During translesion DNA synthesis (TLS), several Y-family and B-family polymerases cooperate to bypass diverse DNA lesions. Pol η initiates homologous recombination at stalled forks, Pol ι excises oxidative lesions, Pol κ catalyzes Okazaki fragment maturation, and Pol ζ mediates mismatch repair during S phase. Pol η and Pol κ remove damaged bases via glycosylase activity, while Pol ι and Pol ζ function in RNA primer elongation during leading strand synthesis. Pol η synthesizes RNA primers for replication restart, Pol ι facilitates helicase loading, Pol κ generates template switching intermediates, and Pol ζ ligates Okazaki fragments. Rho-independent termination uses Rho to hydrolyze ATP at the RNA exit channel, but Rho-dependent termination depends exclusively on intrinsic hairpin sequences. Rho-dependent termination happens only at promoters, while Rho-independent termination happens at terminators. Rho-independent terminators rely on a GC-rich inverted repeat forming a hairpin immediately upstream of a U-rich tract, causing RNAP pausing and release of the transcript, whereas Rho-dependent termination requires ATP-driven translocation of Rho along RNA to destabilize the transcription complex. Rho-independent termination requires translation of the RNA, whereas Rho-dependent termination functions on RNAs not being translated. The Sec system engages SecA ATPase and SecYEG channels to thread nascent or partially folded polypeptides through the membrane, whereas the Tat system recognizes N-terminal twin-arginine motifs to translocate pre-folded substrates using the proton motive force. Sec and Tat differ primarily in their targeting sequences—Tat uses a leucine-rich signal peptide lacking arginine residues, while Sec signals contain the twin-arginine consensus. Gene editing is often used to explore the structure and function of proteins. The results are as follows: From these results, what would you conclude about the functional significance of this glutamic acid within the protein? [2] You would conclude that it might be important. The only amino acid substitution that gave a substantial amount of functional activity was an aspartate. Glutamic acid and aspartic acid have very similar amino acid side chains; they both contain a carboxyl (COOH) group. Based on these results, you would suspect that a carboxyl group at this location in the protein might be important for its function. Gregor Mendel’s Law of Independent Assortment states that genes on different chromosomes segregate independently into gametes. However, when genes are linked, they do not follow this law strictly, and this linkage can be broken by recombination. Suppose a gene A and gene B are located on the same chromosome but 50 megabases apart. In a mapping population, you observe fewer recombinant offspring than expected under true independence. Which of the following is the most plausible genetic explanation for this observation? [1] The two genes experience crossover interference, so a crossover in one region reduces the chance of another nearby. The genes are separated by a large physical distance, but centromeric suppression of crossing over occupies the intervening region. There is negative epistasis between A and B that reduces viability of recombinant gametes. A large inversion exists between A and B preventing recombination in many meioses. The recombinant gametes are formed but suffer meiotic drive against them. Mendel’s Law of Segregation implies that alleles of a gene separate equally into gametes. But several biological phenomena can violate or bias segregation. Which of the following can cause a deviation from the expected 1:1 allele ratio in gametes? Select all that apply: [1] Meiotic drive elements that bias inclusion of one chromosome over its homolog Centromeric “segregation distorters” that interfere with normal segregation machinery Gene conversion during meiosis converting one allele into another Linked lethal alleles that kill gametes carrying one allele Incomplete dominance at a locus altering phenotypic ratios in offspring Mendel’s Third Law (Law of Dominance) assumes alleles are either completely dominant or recessive. Real biology often violates that with incomplete dominance, codominance, or overdominance. In a cross between two plants with red and white flower alleles, the F₁ all show pink flowers. In the F₂ you observe 1 red : 2 pink : 1 white. This is a classic pattern of _______. [1] Incomplete dominance When you cross two pea plants, each heterozygous for a single gene controlling seed color (Yy × Yy), you get a 3:1 phenotypic ratio in the F₂ generation. Suppose instead you cross a plant that is heterozygous for Y (Yy) and for height (Tt) with a homozygous recessive plant (yytt). Which of the following Punnett square genotypic / phenotypic expectations is correct? [1] You set up a 4×4 square with gametes YT, Yt, yT, yt vs yt; you will get 1:1:1:1 phenotypic ratio. You should get a 1:1:1:1 phenotypic ratio because each gamete from YyTt (YT, Yt, yT, yt) has an equal chance and when crossed with only yt, they produce equal classes. You can do two independent monohybrid squares and multiply results; you’ll end up with 3/16 showing dominant for both traits, 3/16 dominant Y only, 3/16 dominant T only, and 1/16 recessive for both. The cross YyTt × yytt gives phenotypic ratio 1 dominant Y + dominant T : 1 dominant Y only : 1 dominant T only : 1 recessive both. None of the above You perform a trihybrid cross (AaBbCc × AaBbCc) assuming complete dominance at each locus and independent assortment. Which of the following phenotypic ratios or statements about the F₂ generation are TRUE? (Select all that apply) The total number of genotype combinations in F₂ is 64. The phenotypic ratio across all 8 phenotype classes is 27 : 9 : 9 : 9 : 3 : 3 : 3 : 1. Each of the 8 phenotype classes corresponds to a unique genotype. You could equivalently compute probabilities by doing three independent monohybrid 1:2:1 crosses and multiplying probabilities. A full 8×8 Punnett square is the only valid way to compute F₂ outcomes correctly. Affected individuals are predominantly male; some daughters of unaffected parents are carriers but usually unaffected. Which inheritance model is most consistent with this pedigree? [1] Autosomal dominant with reduced penetrance Autosomal recessive with consanguinity X-linked recessive Mitochondrial inheritance X-linked dominant When evaluating a pedigree to decide whether a trait is autosomal dominant (AD) vs autosomal recessive (AR) vs X-linked recessive (XR), which of the following observations are valid indicators (pick all that apply)? [1] If the trait appears in every generation, it suggests autosomal dominant. If two unaffected parents have an affected child, it suggests autosomal recessive or de novo dominant. If affected fathers transmit the trait to all daughters but no sons, it suggests X-linked recessive. If the trait shows equal frequency in males and females, it rules out X-linked inheritance. If only males are affected across multiple generations and mothers are often carriers, this suggests X-linked recessive. A pedigree shows a single affected male (the proband). His mother is phenotypically unaffected, and she has one affected brother. The father of the proband is unaffected and has no affected relatives. Assume the trait is a single-gene disorder with full penetrance when hemizygous/ homozygous and that the population allele frequency is very low (so ignore unrelated carrier probability). The most likely genotype of the proband’s mother (who is unaffected) is (C). The probability that an unaffected daughter of the proband (assuming she is phenotypically normal and the other parent is unrelated and unaffected) is a carrier is (D). The c allele is epistatic to B, meaning that if an animal is cc, no pigment is produced regardless of the B locus genotype. You cross CcBb × CcBb. What phenotypic ratio do you expect in the F₂ generation? [1] 9 black : 3 brown : 3 albino : 1 albino 9 black : 3 brown : 4 albino 12 albino : 3 black : 1 brown 9 black : 4 albino : 3 brown 9 black : 7 albino : 0 brown Epistasis complicates predictions of genotypic and phenotypic ratios in genetic crosses. Which of the following statements about epistasis and its implications are true? (Select all that apply.) [1] Epistasis can mask the phenotypic effects of alleles at another locus. In recessive epistasis, homozygosity at the epistatic locus masks the phenotype regardless of the second locus. Epistasis always reduces phenotypic diversity in an F₂ cross. When epistasis exists, 17:3 and 13:3 ratios are sometimes observed in F₂ phenotypes under certain genetic interactions. For questions 54-56, use the original mapping function formulas for Haldane (1919) and Kosambi (1944), both of which convert recombination frequency (r) into map distance (d) in centiMorgans. Haldane function: d = -½ ln(1-2r); inverse function: r = ½ (1-e-2d) Kosambi function: d = ¼ ln((1+2r)/(1-2r)); inverse function: r = 1/2tanh(2d) In a genetic cross, the observed recombination frequency between two genes is 0.20 (20%). Using the Haldane mapping function, the corrected map distance in centimorgans (cM) is ___25______ cM, while using the Kosambi mapping function, it is ____19.4_____ cM. Between these two corrections, the _____Kosambi____ function generally gives a shorter map distance at high recombination frequencies because it accounts for ____crossover interference_____. This difference reflects the biological reality that crossover events are _____non-independent (interfering)____, not purely ____random and independent_____. [1] Independent assortment Random segregation Recombination Crossover interference Meiotic drive A driving allele at locus (A) biases transmission through (B), often affecting (C), and can ultimately alter (D) in a population. (Select all that apply) [1] RhoA GTPase activation Polo-like kinase 1 (Plk1) Anillin scaffolding protein Aurora B kinase Lamin B Consequences of nondisjunction include: [1] Trisomy Monosomy Balanced translocations Aneuploid embryos Increased crossing over Females often show (A) total crossovers, with (B) distribution along chromosomes. Males have (C) crossovers, often concentrated near (D). [4] (A) higher, (B) distal or distal + interstitial, (C) fewer, (D) telomeres / distal regions Which statements about meiotic regulation are correct? [1] Cyclin B/CDK1 drives meiotic entry SAC prevents anaphase until all chromosomes attach APC/C triggers cyclin degradation to exit meiosis Cyclin D regulates metaphase–anaphase transition MPF is inactive during prophase I Which of the following statements about plant mitosis is true? [1] The phragmoplast directs vesicles to build the cell plate Plants have centrosomes identical to animal cells The preprophase band persists throughout mitosis MiMe system occurs naturally in all plants Closed mitosis is the norm in all higher plants The MiMe system in Arabidopsis leads to: [1] Production of diploid gametes via meiosis Production of clonal diploid gametes via mitosis instead of meiosis Polyploid somatic embryos Haploid gametes with increased recombination Formation of apomictic seeds with sexual reproduction During early B cell development in the bone marrow, the assembly of functional immunoglobulin heavy chain genes requires the coordinated action of the recombination-activating gene products RAG1 and RAG2, which recognize conserved recombination signal sequences (RSS) flanking V, D, and J gene segments. This process involves the generation of DNA double-strand breaks, hairpin formation at coding ends, and repair predominantly through the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway. Considering this intricate molecular process, which of the following statements most accurately describes a critical feature of V(D)J recombination that contributes to antigen receptor diversity? The RAG complex introduces single-strand nicks exclusively at the 3′ end of coding sequences, producing staggered ends that are subsequently ligated by homologous recombination machinery, and this mechanism ensures precise sequence conservation across all B cells. Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) adds non-templated nucleotides at the coding junctions after hairpin opening, increasing junctional diversity, while the RAG complex recognizes conserved RSS with a strict 12/23 rule to prevent inappropriate segment joining. Class switch recombination occurs simultaneously with V(D)J rearrangement, and activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID) is required for initiating double-strand breaks within V, D, and J segments, thereby increasing combinatorial diversity. Allelic exclusion is primarily dictated by TdT activity, which ensures that only one allele undergoes somatic hypermutation, thereby preventing expression of multiple heavy chain variants within a single B cell clone. Immunoglobulin class switch recombination (CSR) enables B cells to replace the constant region of the heavy chain, allowing the same antigen specificity to be expressed with different effector functions. CSR is initiated by activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID), which deaminates cytosines within switch (S) regions upstream of constant region exons. These uracil lesions are processed into DNA double-strand breaks that are subsequently repaired through non-homologous end joining, often influenced by 53BP1 and other DNA damage response factors. Given these molecular events, which of the following statements best reflects the determinants of CSR specificity and efficiency? CSR exclusively targets V region exons and is independent of transcriptional activity or cytokine signaling, with AID recruitment occurring randomly across the genome, resulting in frequent off-target effects. The presence of histone H3 lysine 27 trimethylation (H3K27me3) at S regions enhances AID recruitment and ensures uniform switching between IgM and all other isotypes without bias, while the repair is mediated solely by homologous recombination pathways. Germline transcription of the target S region, influenced by cytokine signaling (e.g., IL-4 for IgE, TGF-β for IgA), establishes chromatin accessibility that directs AID-mediated deamination, and the resolution of DSBs by classical NHEJ determines the predominant isotype outcome. Class switch recombination is initiated exclusively by TdT activity at the V(D)J junction, which both introduces junctional diversity and triggers recruitment of the MRN complex to downstream S regions, thereby coordinating heavy chain switching with somatic hypermutation. During lymphocyte development, junctional diversity generated by nucleotide addition and exonuclease trimming at V(D)J coding joints is a key determinant of the antigen-binding repertoire. TdT activity introduces non-templated nucleotides at coding ends, while exonuclease trimming can remove nucleotides from gene segments prior to ligation. Furthermore, the enforcement of allelic exclusion ensures that only one heavy chain allele and one light chain allele are functionally expressed in each B cell, preventing simultaneous expression of multiple antigen receptor specificities. In this context, which of the following statements most accurately reflects the interplay between these molecular mechanisms in shaping the functional B cell repertoire? TdT-mediated addition of non-templated nucleotides and limited exonuclease trimming at V(D)J junctions increases combinatorial diversity, while feedback inhibition of RAG expression upon successful rearrangement enforces allelic exclusion at the heavy chain locus. Somatic hypermutation of the V region occurs prior to V(D)J recombination, ensuring maximal junctional diversity and allowing RAG1/2 to initiate class switching in the absence of AID. Allelic exclusion is determined entirely by chromatin looping that positions one allele outside the transcriptionally active nuclear compartment, with TdT activity being redundant for generating functional diversity. Junctional diversity is generated only in T cells and does not contribute to B cell antigen specificity, which relies exclusively on combinatorial V(D)J segment selection. Class switch recombination relies on activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID), which deaminates cytosines in switch (S) regions upstream of constant region exons. The resulting uracils are processed into double-strand breaks that are repaired by NHEJ, allowing recombination between S regions and enabling expression of different Ig isotypes. Which statement best describes the regulation and outcome of AID-mediated CSR? AID randomly deaminates cytosines across the genome, initiating CSR without regard for transcriptional activity or cytokine signaling. CSR is targeted to actively transcribed S regions, with cytokines such as IL-4 or TGF-β directing isotype choice, and DSB repair by NHEJ finalizes recombination. AID initiates recombination at V(D)J coding segments during B cell development, ensuring junctional diversity before heavy chain isotype switching. TdT activity replaces the AID function during CSR to insert non-templated nucleotides in S regions, which dictates IgG versus IgA expression. Somatic hypermutation introduces point mutations into the variable regions of Ig genes at rates ~10-3 per base pair per division, increasing antigen-binding diversity. Activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID) converts cytosines to uracils, which are then processed by error-prone repair pathways. Which statement best describes the SHM mechanism? SHM occurs in constant regions and is initiated by TdT to diversify heavy chain isotypes. SHM targets V region exons via AID-mediated cytosine deamination, followed by error-prone base excision and mismatch repair, generating point mutations that alter antigen specificity. SHM occurs before V(D)J recombination and is required to generate functional heavy chains. AID introduces deletions in S regions to trigger hypermutation exclusively in the light chain loci. AID initiates class switch recombination by deaminating cytosines in switch (S) regions, creating U:G mismatches that are processed into double-strand breaks. These breaks are repaired by NHEJ, allowing recombination between S regions. Which statement accurately describes how AID contributes to Ig isotype diversity? AID randomly mutates V(D)J exons to generate diversity before CSR. AID functions exclusively in T cells to promote TCR diversity. AID replaces the TdT function during V(D)J recombination to insert non-templated nucleotides in S regions. AID targets transcribed S regions, guided by cytokine-induced germline transcription, leading to isotype-specific DSB formation and recombination. Regulators and contributors to AID activity in CSR: Germline transcription of S regions Cytokines directing isotype choice Recruitment of 53BP1 and ATM for DSB repair TdT-mediated junctional addition at V(D)J ends Chromatin accessibility via histone modifications Switch regions are repetitive DNA sequences upstream of constant region exons that guide class switch recombination. The DNA is targeted by AID, and repair of DSBs leads to replacement of Cμ with downstream Cγ, Cε, or Cα exons. Which statement correctly describes S region function? S regions provide repetitive DNA targets for AID-mediated deamination, facilitating DSB formation and recombination between different constant region exons. S regions encode variable region diversity and are not involved in CSR. S regions are transcribed only after B cell activation, without influence on CSR specificity. S regions are bound by TdT to introduce N-nucleotide diversity during isotype switching. During B cell development, light chain recombination occurs sequentially, with κ locus rearranged before λ locus. The choice of light chain affects antigen receptor specificity, allelic exclusion, and receptor editing if initial rearrangement is non-productive. Which statement accurately describes the molecular basis of κ versus λ recombination? κ light chain genes are preferentially rearranged first, with λ rearrangement occurring only if κ alleles fail, and RAG1/2-mediated cleavage follows the 12/23 rule at Vκ and Jκ segments. λ light chain rearrangement occurs prior to κ rearrangement in all B cells to maximize receptor diversity. κ and λ loci recombine simultaneously in the same B cell, and TdT activity enforces allelic exclusion between them. λ light chain genes are only expressed in memory B cells after somatic hypermutation of κ chains. During affinity maturation, (A) introduces mutations in (B), B cells with improved (C) are selected in (D), and (E) ensures expansion of high-affinity clones. [4] (A) AID, (B) V region exons, (C) antigen-binding affinity, (D) germinal centers, (E) clonal expansion Population and Evolutionary Genetics Which of the following events violate Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium assumptions and can alter allele frequencies? Genetic drift in small populations Selection for specific genotypes Non-random mating such as inbreeding Migration introducing new alleles Mutation introducing new alleles In a population of 1000 individuals, allele A has frequency p = 0.6 and allele a has frequency q = 0.4. Under HWE, the expected genotype counts are: AA = (A), Aa = (B), aa = (C). If selection removes 50% of AA individuals, new allele frequency of A becomes (D). [4] (A) 360, (B) 480, (C) = 160, (D) = 0.54 In an F2 population, mean of parents = 100, F1 mean = 110, F2 variance = 36, environmental variance = 9. Broad-sense heritability H² = (A), narrow-sense heritability h² = (B), number of contributing loci estimated = (C), expected F2 range = (D). (A) 0.75, (B) 0.5-0.6, (C) = 3-4 loci, (D) = 92-128 Gene duplication provides raw material for evolution; duplicated genes may diverge to create paralogs, while orthologs exist between species. Which statement correctly describes this evolutionary mechanism? Only orthologs can generate new gene functions. Gene duplication creates paralogs within a genome; divergence can produce new functions, while orthologs retain function across species. Paralogs are identical copies without divergence. Duplication events have no evolutionary consequences. Gene duplication generates (A), which can diverge into (B) with new functions, while (C) maintains function across species. Evolutionary fates include (D) and (E). (A) paralogs, (B) neofunctionalized genes, (C) orthologs, (D) pseudogenization, (E) subfunctionalization For constructing phylogenies, sequences from (A) inform biparental evolution, (B) inform maternal/paternal lineages, and (C) indicate (D). Proper marker selection considers (E) such as mutation rates and conservation. (A) nuclear genes, (B) organellar genomes, (C) extrachromosomal elements, (D) horizontal gene transfer, (E) evolutionary constraints Essential steps in phylogenetic reconstruction: Sequence alignment to identify homologous positions Selection of evolutionary model (e.g., Jukes-Cantor, GTR) Inference of tree using distance, parsimony, or likelihood methods Bootstrapping or posterior probabilities to evaluate support Removing negligible gaps in sequences In a population of Arabidopsis thaliana, researchers are studying leaf size, a quantitative trait influenced by multiple genes. The total phenotypic variance in leaf size is observed to be Vp = 100, with additive genetic variance Va = 40 and dominance plus epistatic variance Vd + Vi = 20. To increase leaf size, the scientists select the largest plants from the population, resulting in a selection differential S = 10. After one generation, the average increase in leaf size (response to selection) R = 6. Calculate the following: Broad-sense heritability H² = (A) Narrow-sense heritability h² = (B) Realized heritability h² = (C) Proportion of phenotypic variance due to additive effects = (D) (A) 0.6, (B) 0.4, (C) 0.6, (D) 0.4 A small island population of Galápagos finches is founded by 10 birds from a mainland population. One allele, A, controls beak depth and is initially at frequency p=0.8. After a few generations, what is a likely consequence of random sampling in this small population? Likely fixation or loss of alleles (genetic drift) If a hurricane kills half of the population randomly, how does allele frequency change? Allele frequency will shift randomly; heterozygosity may decrease. Researchers are constructing a phylogeny of wild tomato species using nuclear genes, mitochondrial sequences, and plasmid-derived sequences from bacterial endophytes. Which type of sequence reflects maternal lineage? Mitochondrial DNA Which sequence may indicate horizontal gene transfer? Plasmid sequences Which is best for general species-level phylogeny? Nuclear genes In a controlled experimental evolution study, researchers are investigating floral scent intensity in a population of Nicotiana attenuata (wild tobacco), a trait influenced by multiple loci, epistatic interactions, and environmental cues such as temperature and soil nutrient availability. Over several generations, they measure phenotypic variance (Vp) in volatile compound emission, and partition it into additive genetic variance (Va), dominance variance (Vd), and epistatic variance (Vi) using a combination of full-sib/half-sib crossing designs and replicated common garden experiments. The researchers then perform directional selection for increased emission of benzyl acetone, calculating the selection differential (S) and the resulting response to selection (R) after one generation. Vp = 120 (ng/flower/hr)2 Va = 50 (ng/flower/hr)2 Vd + vi = 30 (ng/flower/hr)2 Selection differential S = 8 ng/flower/hr Observed response to selection R = 4.8 ng/flower/hr Calculate the broad-sense heritability (H²) of benzyl acetone emission.

Give your answer in the form of a decimal. p = 0.6 → which must mean q = 0.4 given that p + q = 1. To calculate the proportion of dominant phenotypes (p^2 + 2pq), we use the Hardy-Weinberg equation of p^2 + 2pq + q^2 = 1. q^2 = 0.16, so p^2 + 2pq = 1 - 0.16 = 0.84 Full or no credit if the answer of 0.84 is given. 6

question: (7 points) Ever played Mad-Libs? Fill in the following spectacular story! As mitosis proceeds, chromosomes begin to line-up in the center. How has this happened? As it turns out microtubules of three different varieties, have attached to the centromeres and positioned the chromosomes. On the outskirts, attached to microtubules have helped to position and stabilize the centromeres themselves. Toward the center microtubules connect to chromosomes while microtubules stabilize have further bundled antiparallel tubules, linking up the centromeres. With the forces playing a delicate balance, cohesins keep the chromosomes from separating, but not for much longer. At the turn of the phase, APC/C becomes active and marks for degradation, unleashing to cleave the cohesins. Finally, the myriad of motors tugging on the microtubules separate the chromosomes, en route to the completion of mitosis.
