answer: (7 points) Ever played Mad-Libs? Fill in the following spectacular story! As mitosis proceeds, chromosomes begin to line-up in the center. How has this happened? As it turns out microtubules of three different varieties, have attached to the centromeres and positioned the chromosomes. On the outskirts, dyneins attached to astral microtubules have helped to position and stabilize the centromeres themselves. Toward the center kinetochore microtubules connect to chromosomes while interpolar/non-kinetochore microtubules stabilize have further bundled antiparallel tubules, linking up the centromeres. With the forces playing a delicate balance, cohesins keep the chromosomes from separating, but not for much longer. At the turn of the phase, APC/C becomes active and marks securin for degradation, unleashing separase to cleave the cohesins. Finally, the myriad of kinesin motors tugging on the microtubules separate the chromosomes, en route to the completion of mitosis. Understand, compare and contrast the key stages and structures of mitosis/meiosis Describe the effects of nondisjunction, and use karyotypes to detect chromosomal abnormalities.

question: (1 point each, unless otherwise noted) Back in my day, Protein Modeling was focused on my good friend, cytosine deaminase. Unfortunately, my protein model has shrunk and gotten its hand on a cell with the following DNA sequence with the following template strand:
source: 2026 Yale C_YUSO Designer Genes 2026 Second Draft.pdf
answer: (1 point each, unless otherwise noted, 15 points) Back in my day, protein modeling was focused on my good friend, cytosine deaminase. Unfortunately, my protein model has shrunk and gotten its hand on a cell with the following DNA sequence with the following template strand: TAC ACC AAC CAT TAG TGC GTC TTC TGA AAG TCT CCA GTG CGT CGC ATC AUG UGG UUG GUA AUC ACG CAG UUG ACU UUC UGU GGU CAC GCA GCG UAG a. What nucleic acid is created when cytosine is deaminated? Uracil Before I could fix the issue, my cell replicated its DNA and divided without correction. With my perfect knowledge of my cytosine deaminases activity, I know only one nucleic acid was changed before replication, on the template strand. b. After division, how many mutations will each daughter cell have? Only one in one of the cells, the other is left untouched We already have one mutation going into replication, but we can be fairly certain that no other ones will accumulate during replication. This is due to several tricks that occur during replication. c. (Two points) From binding to initial incorporation, two selective steps are required to incorporate an amino acid. How do both contribute to selectivity? Closing of binding pocket, and catalytic activity. d. While both provide selectivity, the second step is especially important by enhancing selectivity beyond the small hydrogen bond energy difference. What allows for this second step to enforce affinity specificity beyond naive binding? Second binding/use of external energy e. As if all this wasn’t enough, the typical DNA polymerase used in your cells also has this domain to further ensure nothing goes wrong. What is this domain called? Exonuclease f. (4 points) Throughout replication strands will be unwound, bound by external proteins and topological stress will be released, while the new DNA on the lagging strand is stitched together. What are the actors involved in each of these steps and in what order 8 do they begin work (variations accepted for late actors)? Helicase, Single-Strand Binding Proteins, Topoisomerase <-> Ligase. The situation just keeps worsening, as the mutated strand has just been recruited to make a protein. Much to my chagrin, I don’t have knowledge of which cytosine was mutated.. With this in mind, help me work out the possibilities. Assume all associated mutations in the coding strand are to A instead of G (0.5 point each). g. If the first underlined letter is modified, what type of mutation would I end up getting? Nonsense. h. The second? Nonsense. i. The third? Silent. j. The fourth? (Conservative) missense (give them a gold star or something if they say conservative) After it is too late, the DNA glycolases sense something is up. They call on a repair pathway nicknamed BER to repair the damage. k. (3 points) What is BER short for and what two pathways can it take? Base Excision Repair, long/short patch

question: (10 points) Define the role and general locations of each of the following regulatory elements: Promoters: Enhancers: Silencers: Riboswitches: Transcription Factors:
source: 2026 Yale C_YUSO Designer Genes 2026 Second Draft.pdf
answer: (10 points) Define the role and general locations of each of the following regulatory elements: Promoters: DNA sequences located near a gene’s transcription start site that serve as binding sites for RNA polymerase and the transcription initiation complex, enabling transcription to begin. They determine when and where a gene is expressed. Enhancers: Regulatory DNA elements that can increase transcription levels of target genes, often from long distances and in an orientation-independent manner. They function by binding activator proteins that interact with the transcription machinery. Silencers: DNA elements that repress transcription by binding repressor proteins. They reduce or completely shut down expression of target genes, sometimes over long distances. Riboswitches: Regulatory RNA segments, typically found in the 5′ UTR of bacterial mRNAs, that change structure upon binding a small metabolite. This conformational change can activate or inhibit transcription or translation. Transcription Factors: Proteins that bind specific DNA sequences to regulate transcription by recruiting or blocking RNA polymerase. They can act as activators or repressors depending on context. 2 points/term for each correct answer 1 points/term for partial correct answer 0 points/term for no answer or fully incorrect

question: (7 points) Fill in the blanks: The _________________ of molecular biology deals with the flow of genetic information within a biological system. It is often stated as "DNA makes RNA, and RNA makes protein". Transcription is the process by which the information contained in a section of DNA is replicated 11 in the form of a newly assembled piece of _________________. The formed product then finds its way to a ribosome, where it gets translated. In eukaryotic cells, the site of transcription (the _________________) is usually separated from the site of translation (the _________________). The ribosome typically reads the initiator codon first, which is known as _________________ codon which has the triplet base combination of _________. Translation ends with a stop codon which may be triplet base combination of _________, _________, or _________ triplet. _________________ is the transfer of information from _________ to _________ (the reverse of normal transcription).
source: 2026 Yale C_YUSO Designer Genes 2026 Second Draft.pdf
answer: (7 points) Fill in the blanks: The central dogma of molecular biology deals with the flow of genetic information within a biological system. It is often stated as "DNA makes RNA, and RNA makes protein". Transcription is the process by which the information contained in a section of DNA is replicated in the form of a newly assembled piece of messenger RNA (mRNA). The formed product then finds its way to a ribosome, where it gets translated. In eukaryotic cells, the site of transcription (the cell nucleus) is usually separated from the site of translation (the cytoplasm). The ribosome typically reads the initiator codon first, which is known as methionine codon which has the triplet base combination of AUG. Translation ends with a stop codon which may be a UAA, UGA, or UAG triplet. Reverse transcription is the transfer of information from RNA to DNA (the reverse of normal transcription).
